My hon. friend will find that, again and again I have given expression to that opinion, and if this movement for preferential trade has made any progress in Imperial affairs, if there is a party in any part of the empire which is advocating preferential trade, it is largely because Canada has led the way. And if at any time we should be able to bring about that, preference for the benefit of Canada and the other colonies, it will come, not as a result of the policy of hon. gentlemen opposite, who demanded that we should make huckstering terms with John Bull, but as the result of the policy adopted by this government in 1897, which undoubtedly has been a very great factor in the development of Imperial ideas in commercial affairs. Hon. gentlemen opposite nave seen fit to sneer again and again at that preference. We say that it was a good thing for Canada, and for the mother' country. These hon. gentlemen say that it has ruined our factories by admitting a lot of English goods, and then in the next breath say that it never did any good to anybody and has not increased our trade with Great Britain. But if we follow the history of the movement during the last five years, we have every reason to believe that the step taken by Canada has been the chief factor in the creation of an Imperial interest in our commercial and other affairs. I have no difficulty in proving that. Go to the mother country, go to the magazine writers, the daily press, the leading public men, go to the man on the street-aye, and to the utterances of the sovereign from the throne- and you will find all recognize the fact that this preferential trade movement in Canada has been a matter of great concern to the empire at large. And when we can point to that fact, we can afford to listen unmoved to hon. gentlemen opposite who would like to have us believe that it is a matter of no concern at all. On the question of defence, the reply of the government did not state that we would not discuss any such question. It stated that we would, as in duty bound discuss any matter brought before the conference, either by the Imperial government or any of the colonies, and that was the proper view to take. But if my hon. friends opposite think that we are not going far enough in our willingness to enter upon Imperial military expenditure, if they are of opinion that in addition to the moneys we are now spending on the military 87
forces of Canada-and in expending money on the militia of Canada, I claim that we are spending for the defence of the empire- if hon. gentlemen think that in addition, we should enter into a broader scheme of Imperial defence and pay out larger sums that we are now doing for the defence of the empire, they would do well to frame a motion of that character, and assign specially the preparation of that motion to my hon. friend, the member for Jacques Cartier (Mr. Monk), because I am given to understand that when my hon. friend speaks in the province of Quebec, he is not as cordial in his desire for Imperial military expenditure as some of his friends seem to be in this House. Probably that very fact would suggest that before undertaking to commit ourselves on any of the great questions, we should take into consideration not what may commend itself to one section o'f the people or the other, but what is likely to commend itself to the good judgment of the people of Canada as a whole. That, Sir, is the view which the government have taken. We believe that on this question as on others we have given expression to the sober, sensible, thoughtful judgment of the Canadian people. And time will show that we are right.

was the statement which I said was arrant humbug. And, whether it be said by Sir Cnarles Tupper or anybody else, it was arrant humbug then and it is arrant humbug to-day. speechtext:
When the right hon. First Minister was speaking, I felt that it would be my duty to rise and defend the premier of the province of Ontario, the province from which I come. That gentleman has devoted a great deal of time and study to the very question now before the House, but seems to differ, unfortunately, from the right hon. gentleman who leads this House. But before I venture to say a word in defence of the premier of Ontario, let me take the opportunity of saying a word in defence of the right hon. gentleman who now leads the House against the attack made upon him by his follower and colleague the Minister of Finance. (Hon. Mr. Fielding). The Minister of Finance in stentorian tones anathematized anybody who would be so foolish as to demand a preferential duty from the old land. I am not aware that anybody ever did ' demand ' a preferential duty from Great Britain. But the gentlemen on this side have contended again and again that, if the hon. gentlemen opposite would conduct the business according to business methods if, instead of doing as they did with the United States when they wished to make a bargian with them, give everything they had to give and then depend upon the gratitude for a return if they have devoted themselves to the matter in the ordinary methods of business, very possibly the result which the hon. gentlemen opposite affect to desire, and which the hon. gentlemen on this side do most sincerely desire, would have been attained long ere this. The Minister of Finance went on to say that it was a most unreasonable thing for anybody to expect preferential trade away back in 1897. Surely the hon. gentleman is not a student of the modem classics or he would have known that, one of the most beautiful orations ever delivered in this or in any other land was that delivered by the premier in London, on the subject of preferential trade, in 1896. We on this side may differ from the right hon. gentleman as to methods which we think best, or wisest, or most patriotic to promote the development of this [DOT]country. But we bow to no gentleman on the other side in our admiration for the eloquence and ability with which the right hon. gentleman can present his views, such Hon. Mr. FIELDING.
as they may be at any time. In 1896, as I have said, the right hon. premier with even more than his wonted eloquence pointed out the glorious opportunity before Canada, the illimitable possibilities that opened up before us, if the people of Canada would be wise enough to reject the protectionist government which could not attain the boon of preferential trade and put in power a government led by himself and made up of gentlemen whose views of these matters were in accordance with the doctrines of free trade. For he promised to go to the old land and bring back preferential trade which would make this country blossom as the rose. Surely the Minister of Finance has failed to read that speech, or he has forgotten ; otherwise he would not have spoken of the folly and presumption of those who, so long ago as 1897, ventured to propose such a preposterous thing as preferential trade. But, when the right hon. gentleman and his followers came into power they gave us this tariff which gives a preference in our markets to the old country. For what reason they gave it, nobody on this earth can possibly tell to this day, for these hon. gentlemen themselves within the last fifteen minutes have differed as to the reason why it was given. The right hon. premier has told us and told the people of the old country- and thereby won the encomiums of the people there and, possibly won his Cobden medal as much on account of that statement as of any other-that we gave that preference as a matter of gratitude to the mother country. She had done so much for us, and we had done so little for her, that, without seeking or desiring anything, we gave this preference as evidence of our gratitude. And not only we did not expect anything but, we did not desire anything in return. Further, he pointed out most earnestly that any move in the direction of protection would be an injury to the motherland, and so would injure us, the greatest colony. So, the right hon. gentleman did not seek or ask or wish -and perforce, would not accept-a preference from the mother country. Within the last five or ten minutes, the Minister of Finance, who would be supposed to have some faint glimmering ideas as to the reason why this most extraordinary tariff was brought into existence, has told us that there were two reasons for it. One was that it would pay us and the other was that Great Britain would be more likely to give us a preference if we gave her one. Think for a moment;-the right hon. premier tells the benighted Englishmen who were out of sound of the debates in this House and ignorant as to why this tariff was given. We have given you this as a matter of gratitude and nothing else. I can understand how the welkin rang with that shout of loud acclaim that rose to the heavens from the grateful Englishmen who listened to the right hon. gentleman. But what if they had learned, these poor benighted Englishmen,

that, in deed and in truth this was one more of our usual selfish colonial modes, that we gave the preference as the Minister of finance has told us, first because it would pay us, and second that we hoped to get a preference in return ? Now, for my part, I am inclined to stand by the premier. I am inclined to think he understood what he was talking about. For the Minister of Finance, who, after four or five years operation of this tariff would venture to say, on the floor of this House, that any intelligent government passed such a tariff on the ground that it would pay us, does not understand the meaning or operation of that tariff.
And when he went on to say that he gave to Great Britain because, in the second place, he thought we would get something in return, he forgets that we have been told during this very session, and other sessions, and have been told throughout the land, that we gave this tariff to Great Britain not expecting anything under the sun in return, but that we gave this tariff to Great Britain because we owed her a debt which we were going to pay in that way ; for the premier has told us, and we have been told by many speakers on that side of the House, that we gave her that tariff because we owed her a debt of grati-* tude which we intended to pay in that way. And just see how we have paid it. We have said to Great Britain : We owe you a debt, we the people of Canada owe you a debt, but unfortunately we are hard up, money is scarce, we have spent all we had on the first two contingents and we have run short; we cannot afford to give you anything ourselves, and you could not expect a poor country like this, whose brave boys at the front have to live on emergency rations, to pay anything more. And so, as you cannot expect us to give you much in the way of cash, we will pay you by making the woollen manufacturers, the cotton manufacturers, the shirt manufacturers and some other industries in this country square the account with the Yorkshire manufacturers and workmen, so that while we, the people of Canada, cannot afford to pay our debts in cash, we have a few people in Canada from whom we will allow the English manufacturers to collect the money by coming into this market with their goods at the expense of our own manufacturers ; and then we can hold up our hands to heaven and say : Thank Heaven, that debt is paid. I am not prepared to say that the right hon. gentleman and his colleagues have not considerable ground for the line he takes that we cannot afford to pay the old country in cash for the benefits we receive from her. There were other and happier days when we could afford to pay our debts in cash. There was a time when this country was sufficiently opulent that when crimes were committed the government could afford to take all reasonable steps to follow and punish the misdoers. Under the late government that was done 874
again and again, and so determined was the late government to see that justice was done, and so overflowing was the treasury, that even when a Conservative member was accused of wrong doing the most eminent lawyer of the country and he a Reformer, was employed to see that justice was done, and finding him guilty, he was expelled from this House. But even since the hon. gentleman and his friends have come into power, when election frauds were charged in distant Manitoba, money was supplied in abundance and even advanced to private individuals in order that justice might be done and the wrong-doers punished. But since that day we have had much graver offences than those, we have had election scandal after election scandal, until to-day Canada, which once was the most honoured country in the world, I am afraid has some black spots on its escutcheon now ; yet we are so impoverished in this country that ever since the marvellous efforts that were made in 1896, whether rascalities were perpetrated in Brockville, West Huron, Montreal or elsewhere, we have not been able to see that justice was done and the fair fame of Canada vindicated. Now when we find in this way that our money has run short, perhaps we are not to blame if the hon. gentleman should suggest that we take the only means we have in our power of paying our natonal debt.
But before six o'clock is reached, let me say a word in defence of the Hon. Mr. Boss, the premier of Ontario. The right hon. premier of this Dominion laid down the proposition that war and commerce should not go together, and that this letter having been sent over from the old country to the Governor General of Canada, inviting the premier and his colleagues to a conference, they were quite justified in refusing to discuss the question of defence, or in refusing to discuss any question except the commercial one, on the ground that the commercial question and the defence question should not go together. Now, I do not intend to occupy the time of the House in commenting on the terms of this letter in reply, as It is not before us. But it has been laid on the Table of the House, and therefore it is in the possession of the House, and within the knowledge probably of most hon. members. I venture to say there is no member of this House who has read the invitation and the reply, who will not unhesitatingly acquit the right hon. the premier of either writing that reply or of any knowledge of the particular terms of that reply. The language, the spirit, the courtesy of that reply are such as the Minister of Trade and Commerce (Hon. Sir Richard Cartwright) alone could dictate. Neither the right hon. premier or any other of his ministers could have dictated such a response as was sent. It is not necessary for me to recapitulate all the terms of the letter ; but hon. gentlemen will remember

well that whereas the Prime Minister and his colleagues were invited to discuss other questions, and were ashed to make any suggestions in connection with them that they could, they very promptly slapped their prospective hosts in the face, and they very courteously refused to discuss anything but the problem of dollars and cents in which there might be some pecuniary profit. It. would have been quite within the province of the right hon. gentleman to have said at the conference, Canada is not prepared to do anything more in the way of defence than she has done ; he could very properly have taken that course ; but I do submit that nobody will believe that the premier ever dictated or	was aware	of a	reply	sodiscourteous to	his hosts,	who	had	invited the ministers to a banquet, and suggested to them certain topics to discuss. But the premier and his colleagues refuse	to discuss	any	but onequestion. Perhaps some hon. gentleman may say: But look at the last sentence, look, as	it were, at	the	sting	inthe tail ; for after pointing out that no fruitful result could flow from discussing any question but that of dollars and cents, they practically say to their hosts :	If,
however, you are bound to discuss the question of defence, we suppose we will have to listen to what you will have to say. That is the gracious reply His Excellency, on behalf of the government, has sent to the Colonial Secretary in response to the invitation to the right hon. premier and his colleagues.
But the premier of Ontario has discussed this very question. He went through England discussing it at various boards of trade and before other public bodies in the old land. Again and again this question of Imperial defence came up, and the Hon. Mr. Ross, formerly a member of this House, for many years a minister of the province of Ontario, and now for some time back premier of Ontario, pointed out that war and commerce were so closely allied that in his judgment the proper discussion of the defence problem was along commercial lines; that inasmuch as an enormous expenditure is necessary for the purpose of the defence of the empire, and inasmuch as we in the colonies were deriving all the benefits without contributing a dollar, he suggested that a duty of say 5 cents a bushel be placed on all grain brought into the colonies or into Great Britain, or that perhaps the duty might be 5 per cent all round on all products brought into the empire from whatever source, and that the revenue thus derived should be applied as a defence fund, thus making outsiders maintain the army and navy of the empire. Surely, Sir, that is a business proposition. I will go as far as any hon. gentleman on the other side of the House-I say this in answer to the taunt that was thrown out at the hon. member for Jacques Cartier (Mr. Monk) as being opposed to taking part in a scheme for

speechtext:
military defence-I say I will go as far as any hon. gentleman in this House in objecting to any military arrangement that would in any way, no matter how slight, deprive the Canadian people of the control of their own treasury and of their own men. But it is one thing to say we object to handing over to the Imperial authorities the control of Canadian money and Canadian lives, and it is another thing to say that we are not willing to discuss a question whereby, by simply imposing a tax- which would be the very Imperial preferential tariff that the right hon. gentleman claims he desires to attain, that he hopes to get in London, which was the very thing that Mr. Ross hoped to obtain in this simple way-by putting a tax of 5 per cent on all products coming into the empire, we might thus contribute to a common fund for the defence of the empire. Now I venture to say that when a gentleman occupying the position of the premier of Ontario points out this simple, unobjectionable way, and if it were possible even less objectionable since the budget speech of Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, and when the right hon. gentleman says in this House that it is impossible to consider war and commerce together, he takes a position in direct antagonism to the position the premier of Ontario has assumed on that question.

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I regret that I was not in the House when this debate commenced in order that I might have had the full advantage of all that has been said. I desire, however, to express briefly an opinion or two in regard to what has already been said in reference to two or three questions to which attention has been directed. It appears that about two months ago the attention of the country, of the government and of the commercial bodies, such as boards of trades, was directed to the fact that it was the intention of the British government to impose a duty upon corn, or to reimpose, in a degree, the corn laws. The matter was discussed at that time by the various commercial organizations of this country and I know in one, and in perhaps more, cases that the government of this country were approached and that they were pressed to make known the views of the country on this matter and to ask the British government that if these corn laws were reiniposed the colonies of Great Britain should be exempt from the operation of them. Whether the government took the advice which was given to them, or whether they have communicated to the British government on their own behalf, or on behalf of the country, or on behalf of the commercial organizations to

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.

speechtext:
which I have referred, I cannot say. It seems to me, Mr. Speaker, that if they have not done this, they have fallen very far short in their duty. I regret that the right hon. leader of [DOT] the government (Rt. Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier) is not in his place at the present time because if they have not asked the British government to exempt the colonies from the operation of the duties which have been reimposed, I would like to inquire from the government, and to know to-night before this discussion closes, whether it is their intention, now, to press upon the British government to exempt vis from the operation of these corn laws. 1 Would urge them, if they have not done so, to take steps to have the British government exempt us in the way in which 1 have mentioned. It would appear from the debate, so far as it has gone, and it would appear from the attitude of the government for many years past that they have been very sceptical in regard to the question, of whether the British government would at any time within measurable distance reimpose the corn laws or adopt a protective tariff. The hon. Finance Minister (Mr. Fielding) has said that five years ago no one could have expected that these corn laws would have been reimposed, that this duty would have been put in force and that it is because of the war. Certainly we have to look forward to all kinds of contingencies such as war which is one contingency which brings about great results. In view of all kinds of contingencies it does not seem that the government have been very wise in not placing themselves on record and trying to have this country relieved from the operation of this tariff in case, under any circumstances, it should come in force.
The premier gave utterance to a sentiment this afternoon at which I was very much surprised. He took the ground, as I understood it, that defence and commerce are two separate and entirely different things. I wish to disagree with him in respect to this matter. I cannot put myself in the standpoint of the Prime Minister when he makes such a statement, because, it seems to me, Mr. Speaker, that great navies are chiefly for the purpose of defending the commerce of the nations which own these great navies, that were it not for the commerce of the countries there would not be so much money spent in naval defence. I think that the ground is not well taken when the premier puts forth such a statement as that. The navy of Great Britain is increasing constantly. For what purpose is it increasing ? The navy of Germany is increasing and for what purpose V The navy of the United States is increasing. Is it not to defend the continually increasing foreign trade of the United States, of Germany and of Great Britain ? These are civilized nations ; they are not seeking for territorial extension at the present time so
much as to develop their trade and commerce and the navies upon which they spend so much money are for the purpose of enabling them, in case of complications, to defend that commerce. Therefore, I say that trade and defence go hand in hand, and while it is a very nice sentiment for the Prime Minister to talk about developing this country along other lines, and not to direct our attention to the question of military and naval expenditure so much, yet, we must be guided by what other nations have to do and we must come to the conclusion that we cannot be exempt from these obligations and responsibilities which other nations have to assume. The Prime Minister also referred to the fact that we lia'd done an Imperial work in building the Canadian Pacific Railway. I have heard that argument advanced on former occasions and by other gentlemen. The Canadian Pacific Railway has paid this country fourfold over all it cost us, but we have other great enterprises in this country .besides the Canadian Pacific Railway. We have other railways, we have other public works, we have canals, we have bridges, we have wharfs, and I think, Sir, that these would only be secondary to the_ Canadian Pacific Railway in these discussions in using such things as arguments, if, in fact, any of these things, and including the Canadian Pacific Railway, can be considered in any sense to have been built from an Imperial standpoint. I say that it is no argument and no excuse why we should not assume our fair share of responsibility in relation to the defence of the country that we should point to such matters as these. The right hon. gentleman also said that we did not want to turn the finances and revenues of the country in the direction of defence, that it would be better to spend the money on public works. I will admit, that, perhaps, it might be better, but we have to accept the inevitable. We cannot get away from these facts.
Now, I have said in this House on many occasions that I did not believe there was any other destiny for this country except that of British connection. I wish to reiterate that statement, and I wish to say that I hope the time is coming when we will all agree on that matter. I believe there is no medium course for us, that there is no course for us such as independence. I believe that if there was a sentiment, which I question very much, there is no such sentiment on the part of our people looking towards independence as would make it a practicable question, because, assuming that we were granted independence, in a very few years we would be absorbed by the United States, I admit after a struggle, but the struggle would be inevitable because the conclusion would be foregone.

speechtext: And supplemented their pay.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
And supplemented their pay. However, for some reason or other the government have gone back on the principle they acted upon at the outset of the hostilities. Why they have done this is a mystery to me. It must be apparent that if they were right in the first instance, they were wrong in the second ; if they were right in equipping, clothing and transporting the men

of the first two or three contingents, they were wrong afterwards in not doing the same with regard to the subsequent contingents. We cannot say that in the paltry expenditure they incurred for this service, they did their whole duty to the empire. The contingent which is in course of organization at the present time, as I understand, are offering themselves for service in South Africa, and the ordinary citizen cannot possibly take any credit to himself, because the men who are offering themselves are doing all the sacrificing. The government as I understand, is not willing even to clothe them or give them a water bottle or a rifle. The young men are enthusiastic. We were told the other day by the Minister of Militia that three were offering where only one was needed. This is an evidence of the condition of public opinion in this country. It is quite evident that if five thousand were needed, they would be forthcoming. This being an evidence of the condition of public opinion in this country, I say that the government have taken a wrong stand in this matter also. I think it is an injustice to our young men that they should be put in that position. If the British government wanted men, they could get them from the semi-civilized tribes of India or Africa on the same conditions. Have we or have we not any interest in this matter ? Do we not feel that it is a good thing for this empire to be held together ? And is there not merely a sentimental reason for this, but a commerejal one also? If it had not been for the great efforts and sacrifices which Great Britain has made, and the lesser sacrifices which the colonies have made, all this could not have been accomplished, but the whole structure would have fallen to pieces. Not only would Great Britain have been deprived of her possessions in South Africa, but that would have been the beginning of ! the end. Therefore I say that the govern- ' ment made a mistake in this matter, and I deplore the way in which men who have i volunteered to go forward have been treated. , I contend that if Great Britain had desired j to obtain troops upon the conditions which , these Canadian soldiers have gone forward, , she could have got them in other parts of , the globe, and we in Canada should only f have sent forward as many men as it was ; possible for us to clothe, equip and frans- , port at the expense of Canada. When we ^ have an over-flowing treasury, and such sur- s pluses as the Minister of Finance boasts of, l and when we are spending so little on defence, we cannot say that we have done s our whole duty when we have spent a couple of million or so on the first contingents. From a monetary point of view we ( cannot be excused. The sentiments and j principles of these young men have been j established, because they have continued to ( volunteer after others returned from the E war, and after they knew of the privations, c Mr. KEMP.
the sufferings and the dangers which were before them.
The government have, in respect to the despatch of these contingents, simply occupied the position of outfitters. They have on behalf . of the British government, the British taxpayer, purchased the clothing, arms, and equipment, which any commercial organization could have done. We have one citizen of this country, with sufficient national sentiment and money, who organized, equipped and sent out to South Africa a contingent at his own expense. It is a pity that we have not had others with sufficient wealth to do likewise and thus to have relieved this government from responsibility which they have evidently een loath to assume. I do not wish to take up the time of the House any further. It is. a good thing for this country that we have young men such as those of whom we have read within the last few days-men such as Private Evans and Gap-tain Canruthers. If we did not have such material in this country, we could never expect to build it up as we hope to do. These men are the kind who have helped materially to build up other great nations, and I am sorry I have to say of this government that I believe it has pursued with regard to them a picayune policy. To my mind the government have made three mistakes. Their first was the reply which they gave concerning the question of Imperial defence. The second, is their attitude in reference to the contingents, and the third is the position in which they find themselves, owing to the re-imposition of the corn laws in Great Britain. Now that the right hon. Prime Minister is in his place, this House would be very much interested if he would tell us whether he lias up to the present, at the instance of the commercial organizations which petitioned him in respect to this question, approached the British government and asked it to exempt Canada from the affect of the tax imposed on bread stuffs. These commercial bodies foresaw two months ago what was likely to happen, and petitioned the right hon. gentleman to do (Something. But if no steps were taken during the past two months, I would like to have the right hon. gentleman say that steps will immediately be taken to ask the British government to give us a preference. I believe, from the reports in the papers this evening, that if such representations were made, Canada would be exempt from the application of the tax which has been imposed upon her wheat and other cereals.

I do not know that I should have thought of saying anything in reply to my hon. friend from Toronto (Mr. Kemp), had it not been for the repetition, in the latter course of his remarks, of the attacks upon the position of the gov-

ernment with respect to the sending of the contingents to fight for the empire in South Africa. My lion. friend enjoys the distin-tion of being more loyal to the King and more Catholic than the Pope, and in that respect he seems to have a considerable amount of -support in the good city in which he resides. He finds fault with us for not hraving done what he thinks we should have done. He finds fault because we have not paid what we were not asked to pay.
speakername: The MINISTER OF THE INTERIOR (Hon. Clifford Sifton).

speechtext: Oh.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
And what it was not even suggested we should pay. The House knows well that when the question of sending a contingent first came before us, the government promptly responded to the call and did everything -to the letter which it was suggested the government should do. But our hon. friends even then were so anxious to find fault with the government that they contended that, in addition to supplementing the pay of our forces in South Africa, we ought to pay the rest of the money, although the British government were willing to pay it and never made any suggestion to us that we should do so. And they find fault with us because, in the case of this last contingent, we have not assumed a position different from that which it was suggested we should assume.
The British government, desirous of securing a number of colonial troops, made a suggestion to a number of colonial governments, and that suggestion was loyally responded :to by every government to which it was made, and by none more promptly and loyally than the government of Canada. In respect of the contingent being formed to-day, we are doing everything it has been suggested we should do, and if anything further be necessary, we are ready and willing to do whatever else may be suggested. Surely that is an attitude -in which the country will ibe disposed to support the government. And it is an attitude, in respect of which we can claim the support of the House and the country. But I venture to say that my hon. friend, in the remarks which he has addressed to this House, cannot claim the support of the House and the country. I venture to say that he cannot get the members on his own side to endorse the position he takes. I venture to say that he cannot get his leader in this House to -endorse the statements he has made and put them in the shape of a resolution. We are here, Sir, for the purpose of doing business, and not for the purpose of airing theories which we know are not going to be adopted. We are not here for the purpose of making -suggestions which cannot be carried into practical effect. That is not what the government is here for, whether that be what my hon. friend is here for or not. We are here for the purpose of dealing with practical business, and we have dealt with these contingents in a
practical business way, and we submit our conduct to this House and the country, confident that it will meet with their approval. Let my hon. friend get his leader to submit his policy to his friends in the House and the country, if he desires to have even respectable attention given to the suggestions he makes. This government and the Liberal party generally have no cause to feel ashamed of their position with regard to -sending troops to assist in fighting the battles of the empire. Hon. gentlemen opposite when -in opposition are very loyal, so far as their lips are concerned, but it is a matter of history that when they had an opportunity of doing what we have done, they did- not do it. They -did not supplement the pay, they -did not pay the expense, they did not send the men, although the suggestion was made that they should do so, when Britain was -in war in the Soudan, and other British -colonies were busy sending assistance -to the mother country. Where was Canada then ? Canada was then governed by the party of which the hon. gentleman is so enthusiastic a member. But Canada was not then in -the van of the fighting line. It lagged behind until the Liberal government took office. Since then it has not lagged behind but has gone forward and assumed a position in the councils of the empire which it never enjoyed before, and which it never would have assumed if we were left to follow -the theor-tical and unpractical counsels which the hon. gentleman suggests. The hon. gentleman has had some experience himself in endeavouring to formulate an imperial policy, but his experience -has -not been satisfactory, to the extent a-t least of making any impression on -the minds of the statesmen who govern the empire. What is the occasion of this debate ? Why has it been brought on ? So far as -my hon. friend from East York (Mr. Maclean) is concerned, I think we can all answer the question. The hon. member for East York could not resist the temptation-he never can-of being first to bulletin an important piece of news from his place in this House. His instinct as a newspaper man leads him to highly prize that privilege, and I think we all regard it as one of the things that may be expected of him and all rather enjoy it. But, so far as this debate has developed into an attack upon the policy of the government, I desire to point out that it is of a piece with the policy that has been followed by the hon. gentlemen on the other side with respect to the action of the government in connection with the affairs of the empire from the day we took office. It is a deliberate and persistent attempt to misrepresent the position of the government to the House and to the people. When we were in opposition the hon. gentlemen did the same thing. They were exceedingly loyal, and they declared that if we came into office the affairs of the British empire would not be safe, so far as our influence upon them was concerned.

But the moment we proceeded to give a practical evidence of our affection for the empire and our loyalty to it, what did they do ? No sooner was that resolution laid on the Table than they proceeded to show that they were opposed to that policy and to any policy that gave practical expression of Canada's loyalty to the empire. A little later on when the right hon. Prime Minister went to England what happened ? They were afraid of the effect of the success of the visit of the right hon. gentleman to the mother country, of the reception he met with there and the favourable impression he created upon the minds of the people. Fearing that these things would reflect upon their political fortunes, they proceeded to misrepresent what he had said, and to say repeatedly, yet without a shadow of foundation, that he had refused an offer that had been made of preferential treatment of Canadian products in the British market, or that he had declined in advance an offer that was about to be made. It took a considerable length of time to explode that misstatement. And now, we have the same thing going on. We find these hon. gentlemen trying to create the impression in the House and in the country that there is something in the position of this government that is not favourable to preferential trade, in fact, that we have declared ourselves hostile to it. I know of no case of any person who has any authority to speak on behalf of the Liberal party having declared himself hostile to preferential trade or having attempted to minimize its beneficial effects if it were possible to secure it. What was said repeatedly was that it was not likely that such a thing would come about in the very near future. As my hon. friend the Minister of Finance said it is simply a question of when the opportune time was. Was the time opportune in 1897 when my hon. friend the Finance Minister laid his budget on the Table and brought down this British preference proposal ? If the time was opportune in 1897, was it not opportune in 1896, when hon. gentlemen opposite were in power ? There was no striking change in the affairs of the empire between 1896 and 1897. If the members of this government could have got preferential treatment in 1897 why did not the Conservative government get it in 1890 ? Simply to call attention to the fact is all that is necessary to show that the thing is not arguable, that it is a statement that does not commend itself to the most easily deluded person. Now, these hon. gentlemen find that circumstances have arisen which make it possible that in the future, perhaps in the near future, the question of preferential freat-ment may be a subject of serious discussion. Nobody knows better than these hon. gentlemen do that the action of this government for the last five years has commended itself to the government of Great Britain and to the people of Great Britain.

speakerposition: Minister of the Interior; Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs

speechtext:
Nobody knows better than they do that Canada at the present time is strong in the mother country ; and if, under the circumstances in which the empire is placed, it be possible to do anything to meet the wishes of Canada, it will be done. That is what we all feel and we feel it and know it to be the result of the course of action followed by this government for the last five years-a course of action that was diametrically opposed not only to what hon. gentlemen opposite propose now, but to what they carried out when they were in power, their policy of keeping Great Britain at arms length, of giving nothing unless they got an equivalent. Now that they see the time approaching when a discussion is likely to take place upon this question, they desire to make it appear to the people that this government approach the discussion of that subject in the coming conference in a hostile spirit. There is no foundation for such statement. On the contrary, every member of this government looks forward to the conference with the strongest hope and desire that something may be done to improve our trade relations, not only with Great Britain but with the other colonies of the British empire. And if Great Britain finds itself on account of its revenue necessities in a position to consider an idea which Lord Salisbury would not entertain two years ago, we say that we have been favoured by fortune and shall be most happy to take advantage of the opportunity thus presented. There is nothing whatever in the document to which the hon. gentleman referred which justified the misrepresentations made this afternoon. It is a document which, I venture to say, is calculated,to do that which it ought to do. It is calculated to convey to the British government what is in the minds of the advisers of the Crown in this country-that we regard the commercial question as the practical question, the question from which results may be expected, but that as to the other questions, while we are prepared to discuss them, we do 'not at the present time feel that there is likely to be any tangible or practicable result. If the gentleman's own views were written down, I venture to say they would be expressed by that memorandum. The hon. gentleman himself knows, I am sure, just as well as we do, that the commercial question is the one from which practical results may follow, but that the other questions while they may be discussed are not likely to yield any practical results at the present time. And if we have expressed, as I venture to say we have, the mind of nine-tenths of the members of this House on both sides, and of nine-tenths of the members of the Canadian community, I do not see why the hon. gentleman should take the trouble to waste the time of the House in finding fault. I did not wish to take up time this evening, but I desired to call attention to the position

that the government has taken with regard to the contingent, upon which the hon. gentleman made an attack, and I take it that it is quite clear that the position that the government has taken is one that will commend itself both to the House and to the country.

The House has now listened to three members of the. Cabinet address thetnselves to the task they have in hand, and that it is a task is quite evident from the fact that tlie question of real importance that has been raised, and that will be regarded as real importance throughout this country, has not been answered by any of them. The whole question at issue is whether or not this government proposes to address itself to the task, if it is a task, of obtaining from the British government favourable treatment for Canada in this question of grain importation into the motherland. I can easily understand why these hon. gentlemen are ashamed to deal with this question. I can easily understand why they feel diffident in approaching it. The fact is they find themselves in a pit and they are unable to extricate themselves. What is the history of the question of British preference ? In the autumn of 1896 when the elections were being proceeded with, the present premier went into the province of Ontario. Sir Charles Tupper had introduced the question of British preference, and the premier who was then the leader of the opposition found that he had to do, as he has always done, and I suppose always will do-he had to trim his sails to catch the wind.
Finding that that was a popular cry in the province of Ontario, in his celebrated London speech which has been referred to this afternoon, the hon. gentleman went strong, and endeavoured to go Sir Charles Tupper one better on the question of a preference for our food stuffs within the Bri-ish market. Then he found himself face to face with his pre-election utterances. Later on he found himself in Great Britain, and true to his free trade principles, he at once placed himself in communication with gentlemen who had the same political aptitudes as himself. My recollection is that there was a meeting held in the city of Liverpool, that a banquet was tendered to the right hon. gentleman, and that on that occasion" his first utterance was along the line that Canada did not want any preference in the British market at all. Now the right hon. gentleman 'was in one of two positions < Either he was not politically honest when he preached that doctrine of preferential free trade, or he was in a position where he might accomplish it but did not wish to accomplish it. Be that as it may, the right hon. gentleman's statements were acclaimed, and I think on more than one occasion, in addressing meetings in different parts of Great Britain, banquets which were tendered him, he went on this self same cry again, that no preference was desired and no preference sought by the Canadian people. So strong were his statements in this regard that he was at once heralded by the celebrated Cobden Club as an apostle of free trade from protectionist Canada. If reports be true, although I have never seen that precious article, the right hon. gentleman had the honour of having pinned on his breast the Cobden medal which, on more than one occasion, he has been advised that he holds to-day under false pretenses, heading as he does a protectionist government in Canada, and that a quick return should be made of that medal, which must be now a much despised article because it has never been paraded in this country.
Now, what is the position of these hon. gentlemen to-day ? The Conservative party have held the right hon. gentleman and his government to task from the very moment they stood on the threshold of office, in that they have not tried to impress upon the home authorities the desirability of carrying this policy into effect. As the Minister of Finance stated this afternoon, five years ago it was an absurdity to ask for that, and he said to-night that we would not have been greeted with the news that we have heard to-day of this imposition on flour and grain, were it not that this impost was rendered necessary by the exigencies of the war. Well, that is rather a prophetic declaration for that hon. gentleman. But he must remember that he and his colleagues have always fairly laughed the matter out of court in this respect, and have contended that so long have these duties been abandoned in Great Britain that it was impossible that she should ever have recourse to them again. The hon. gentlemen have proceeded on these lines, and their press has gone on these lines ; but when they are confronted with the information that has come to-day from Great Britain, they are startled, it is almost too quick a turn for them to take ; and they are in this dilemma, that they cannot to-night inform the House whether they intend to ask the home government to make that concession. Now how is this news being greeted in Great Britain ? I find in the Montreal ' Star ' of to-day a despatch from New York containing the correspondence of the New York ' Evening Post ' to this effect:
Almost before the Chancellor of the Exchequer had resumed his seat in the House of Commons, yesterday afternoon, the streets were ringing with the news-hoys' cries of ' tax on bread !' Thus beginning an agitation with a possible serious sequel.
Taxes on wheat and flour, practically, is a return to the duties which were enacted after the repeal of the old protective corn law. Influential supporters of the ministry intend to press for the complete exemption of Canadian and Australasian grain, as a response to the colonial preferential tariffs and some recognition of Colonial help in the war.

Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, almost alone among the ministers, stands between them and success.
Now this afternoon I listened to the Minister of Finance's exposition of their policy. While with one breath he said that the whole preference to Great Britain was sentiment, _ in the next place he said it was really a " sordid proposition on the part of the government, that they went to Great Britain with this proposition, not out of sentiment, but with the hope and expectation that some day later on a preference might be given to Canada. To-day these gentlemen are brought face to face with the fact that they have been slow in the past, and they find themselves in a dilemma. Let us go a little further and read another quotation which I have here, showing how this matter is being viewed by persons from other colonies. In the Montreal ' Star ' of to-day a number of gentlemen are interviewed on the situation, and one gentleman gives this opinion :
Mr. Caldwell, of the firm of Steen, Maeky, Logan and Caldwell, of Auckland, New Zealand, who is at present in Montreal, expressed the opinion that the business men of his country would be disappointed at the new budget. In discussing the matter to-day, he said that, while New Zealand had not given Great. Britain a preference in her tariff, the people were perfectly Willing to do so, provided it was placed on a reciprocal basis. He did not understand how Canadian- manufacturers could prosper under the present tariff.
Now there is the opinion of a gentleman from New Zealand who, I presume, is a gentleman of prominence, as his opinion has been sought by a journal of the importance of the Montreal ' Star.' This fact is evident, that the members of the government have been caught suddenly by this proposition of the British government, and they are now endeavouring to back up and wait for public opinion. They are endeavouring to force the opposition, if possible, to take the ground that we are in favour of a defence fund for army and navy purposes, in order to precipitate a discussion along those lines so that they might strengthen themselves in the House and in the country. Well, it is no new game for these hon. gentlemen to stand and wait for public opinion and popular approval. We have seen that in connection with the question of sending the contingents. Why, if there ever was a question agitated before the people of Canada on which the government stood, and halted, and waited for popular opinion before they moved, it was on the question of the first contingent. Why, Sir, it was the scandal of the country, and day in and day out the ministry were at daggers drawn on that very question. The ' Patrie ' newspaper, controlled by the Minister of Public Works, who, as the country knows, is the master of this administration, declared day after day that there would be no contingent; and afterwards when these contingents were sent Mr. BENNETT.
there were apologies all along the line from these hon. gentlemen. If I recollect rightly it was the Minister of Inland Revenue (Hon. Mr. Bernier) who apologized on different platforms in the province of Quebec at the last elections, for the presence of those men in South Africa who had gone from Canada. The whole plea of the government was that these men had not been sent by the Canadian government, but that this government had in their wisdom [DOT] simply allowed these men to go from Canada to South Africa. These hon. gentlemen are in this position to-day, that they have failed to keep abreast of the times, people are holding them to account on this question of preferential trade, and for missing an opportunity that would probably have been theirs had they grasped for it. To-day they are endeavourig to draw a herring across the path, they are endeavouring to force this side of the House into taking some stand that can be used in the province of Quebec. The Prime Minister made a speech to-day that he cannot deny will be used both in Ontario anid in Quebec. The right hon. gentleman struck the keynote when he said that he was opposed and opposed fairly and squarely to this question of giving assistance to the empire in strengthening her armaments, whether they be naval or whether they be forces in the field. I think that was plainly understood. When the right hon. gentleman came up to the fence he saw the dilemma with which he was confronted and I assume that he thought it would be better to take a position of anti-imperialism, as it is termed in the province of Quebec, and then to approach the people in the other provinces by simply presenting the question in the shape of a commercial matter. But, I can tell the right hon. gentleman that there has grown up in Great Britain a strong feeling in favour of a preference being given to our food supplies in that country and I believe it has been hastened, not by the question of this so-called preference which has been given under our tariff, but that the feeling has been strengthened in Great Britain by reason of that fact that our valiant sons volunteered their lives in defence of the empire in South Africa.

Hr. Speaker, I am not surprised that the hon. gentleman who has just taken his seat, after the manner in which this question has been discussed by his colleagues on the other side of the House, should presume to say that he desired that there should be some definite question placed before the House to-night to be decided by a vote. Hon. gentlemen understand that the question before the House is whether the Speaker should leave the Chair or not, for us to take up the work of the Committee of Supply ; and our hon. friends on the other side of the House, on that very simple resolution, have discussed almost every question that has come up in the party politics of Canada in the last four or five years. They have discussed the question of the contingents and the attitude of the Liberal party and that of their party on that question ; they have discussed the question of the preferential tariff which was framed by the present government ; they have discussed almost every other question which has come within the lines of party politics. My hon. friend from Hastings reduced the whole discussion down to a question of politeness, as to whether the answer of the government to the invitation of the Imperial government was couched in sufficiently polite terms-in other words whether this government should not have said that they would cheerfully discuss all the questions laid before them by Mr. Chamberlain in his invitation. Unfortunately for us, if there should be a vote on this question, we shall be called upon to vote at random. If our hon, friends would consent to confine the discussion to any one of these questions, it would be far more satisfactory ; and the repeated invitation they have had to formulate their views in a resolution, so that we might bind them to some declaration of policy, has a great deal of force in it. I do not think it rests in the mouth of hon. gentlemen opposite to charge this government witn a lack of policy on these questions, when they are so notoriously divergent upon them. Perhaps before this debate is through we shall hear from the hon. member from Jacques Cartier (Mr. Monk) as to his views on the contingents-whether the contingents which are now being sent to South Africa under the auspices of the Dominion government, and tile contingents which went before, should be paid for by this government, and as to whether the government of Canada should enter into negotiations with the government of Great Britain for the purpose of establishing a large scheme of imperial defence. Many hon. gentlemen on the other side of the House take a stand that this government should be bound to join with the mother country in a large and broad scheme of imperial defence. I would like to see hon. gentlemen opposite united on
these questions before they charge the government of the day with being disunited upon them. The party opposite has always claimed to be pre-eminently the party of imperialism and of extreme loyalty to the mother country ; and yet I have listened in vain to-day for one word of sympathy with the people of the mother country for the enormous burdens which they have laid upon themselves in maintaining the dignity and prestige of the empire in South Africa ; and in view of the fact that the Chancellor of the Exchequer has to meet a deficit of fifty or sixty million pounds sterling in the current year, I think that hon. gentlemen opposite might have looked at that phase of the question. It is all very well to speak of the small duty which is proposed to be levied on wheat and corn as a protective policy ; but any one who knows anything of a protective, as compared with a revenue policy, must admit that this is a portion of a revenue policy pure and simple. The position of the mother country is that notwithstanding this small duty and the increase of the income tax and of the stamp tax, there will still be a deficit of about thirty million pounds which must be raised by a revenue bill. Any one who looks fairly at the facts of the case cannot believe that this is the entering wedge of a protective policy in regard to foodstuffs. So far as the Dominion of Canada is concerned, while I believe every man in Canada, whether Liberal or Conservative, would be willing and glad to see some preference given to our products in the mother country, and would welcome it as a response to the fraternal feeling displayed by Canada in her preferential tariff, yet I feel that we should not go to the mother country, either in times of peace or in times of stress, to huckster and bargain with her on questions of this kind.
I was somewhat surprised that any gentleman, particularly the hon. member who has just spoken, should have ventured to assert that the Prime Minister said in another country that Canadians did not want any preference in the British market. It is true that when brought to task by my hon. friend from Welland (Mr. German,), he varied the assertion somewhat by declaring that what the Primq Minister said was that he would not then ask any preference for the Dominion, as a consequence of the preference we were giving. Before resuming his seat, however, he again repeated his original story, which he utterly failed to prove. One would suppose that the hon. gentleman would have been prepared with a quotation and the day and the date, to substantiate the statement he made, but nothing of the kind. Now there is considerable distinction in stating that Canadians did not want a preference and declaring that we) were not basing the preference we offered on a reciprocal preference by the mother country; and to have demanded such reciprocal pre-

ference would have been perfectly useless at the time, because a duty on breadstuffs was a thing no one then contemplated. It would have been considered as something outrageous for any public man to have insisted on the British government placing a duty on the foodstuffs of the British people. But since, in the stress of war, it has become necessary for the British government to raise more revenue by means of a tariff on breadstuffs, which previously was undreamed of, there might be some reason for expecting that the preference given the British in our market, which aroused so much enthusiasm in the mother country, which did so much to draw us together, might possibly be reciprocated. Upon the general subject of our relations to the mother country much no doubt will be said before the close of the present session, and I may be pardoned if I express my own views on that question, in which, I think, my colleagues about me largely share. The commercial relations between the colonies and the mother country and the Imperial defence are two entirely separate questions. The question of Imperial defence is one upon which the people of this country are by no means a unit, one upon which the Conservative party is not a unit, and it is possibly one upon which no inconsiderable number of people in the Dominion have formed no positive conclusion. We all know the strong opinion held by Sir Charles Tupper on this point. We all know the intensity of the language he used when denouncing the very idea of the Dominion being bound in any way to meet any of the charges in the British Exchequer with regard to imperial defence. And he has many followers in the Conservative party. The principles as laid down by him I think were very sound. In defending our own territory, in providing an adequate force for the defence of Canada, and in carrying on our internal legislation in such a way as to make Canada strong and prosperous and cultivate a strong feeling of solidarity of the empire in Canada-all these things are sufficient guarantee that we will be ready when the circumstances require us to bear our share in the defence of the empire. The government has been charged with slackness of duty, and odiums attempted to be thrown on it for not having voted larger sums in support of the South; African contingents. I do not think that the financial aid of Canada is by any means so important to the mother country as is taken for granted by some hon. gentlemen opposite. What the statesmen and the British people do appreciate and admire is the spirit of loyalty and enthusiasm with which we responded to the call of the empire in South Africa. The noble enthusiasm which our sons manifested in laying upon the altars of their country their lives, prospects and honour stirred the pulse of the English people. That which they admired was not any contribution in money or financial re-88
sources, but the contribution of sentiment, zeal and loyalty which we sent in the person of our sons who went to fight the battles of the empire in South Africa. Not only we, but the people of the mother country, are proud of the young men who thus proved their courage, ability and devotion to their country, and who have not only gained a high place in the esteem of their own countrymen, but have done a great deal to excite admiration for Canada in the minds of British statesmen and people. And when the colonial and British statesmen meet at London to plan closer commercial relations between the colonies and the mother country, if they come to a wise solution of this question, that will solve ail the others. I agree with the right hon. the First Minister that there is a vast difference between being united for the purposes of war and united for the purposes of commerce, and that we ought to keep these two questions separate and distinct. It seems to me that in the time of stress and trial through which the mother country is passing, and when she has to impose a duty on breadstuffs, it is only a narrow spirit which would prompt us to clamour immediately to be relieved from all the weight and burden of that duty. We can safely leave this matter to the Imperial instincts of the British government and people, confident that the part which Canada has played will inspire them with a desire to settle this question in our interests as well as theirs. I hope, in the meantime, that our hon. friends opposite will come to a conclusion as to the stand they propose to take, and that when they succeed in finding themselves in a position to formulate a policy, they will do so that we may know exactly where they are, which it is impossible to say at present.
