The Prime Minister and every one of his supporters said that it could not be obtained. Well, it is possible to obtain it now. The right hon. gentleman is going to discuss our commercial relations when he gets to the old country. But he has stopped discussion on all political questions, and on all questions of imperial defence which are so intimately connected with our commercial relations that he will not be able to accomplish anything. He has given a death blow to everything in the shape of the furtherance of imperial ends, by that answer of his to the imperial authorities. We want the despatches. We want the despatch which the Colonial Secretary sent to Lord Minto, and we want the answer of this government to that despatch. These are not down. I draw your attention to these words :
With a view to the proposed conference, hope your piomier will he able to remain for a short time, say three weeks, after the ceremony, as the guest of His Majesty's government. Please telegraph reply. Despatch follows.
We would like to get that despatch.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I may say to mj hon. friend that there is no despatch. Though it was stated that a despatch was coming, it has never come.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I was judging by the telegram, which seems to me to be a very short one. The despatch must have been countermanded, because when the Colonial Secretary received the reply of the right hon. gentleman, that ended all communications with the government on that subject. I do not wonder that he sent no more despatches.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The reply was so satisfactory to the British government that they did not need to say anything more. -

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
It was so satisfactory that they had no further communication on the subject. There is no chance for a despatch now. All chance for negotiation is very likely at an end. When the British government received the reply of the right hon. gentleman to the despatch,
that ended all hope of any intercolonial arrangements, either as defence or the political relations of the colonies to the empire, or even as to their commercial relations.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: What are the dates ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The telegram of the Colonial Secretary is the 23rd of January, and the reply of the government here is the 3rd of February. We have no despatch, there is an end to the communications altogether, and the right hon. gentleman will simply be a pageant at the Coronation show, and no political results will follow from what ought to be the best and brightest opportunity that was ever offered to a people to accomplish their wishes and wants.

Motion agreed to, and House went into Committee of Supply.
Statistical Year-book, $i,000.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The hon. minister was to give us some details as to how the distribution of this book was made.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The Year-book is distributed to mechanics' institutes, to the press, and to the public libraries in the country. A number are also sent to libraries and different offices in England : also to boards of trade and similar public institutions, and of late years a certain number have been distributed to members of the House. The distribution of the book has been materially increased of late.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I think that is precisely the information which the hon. gentleman gave us on a former occasion. What he was asked to do, and what he promised to do, was to give the committee the number distributed in each case.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I asked for that information from the statistician, but I am afraid I have not got the paper here.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: One class of institution which I think ought to be supplied with these books are the collegiate institutes, which have a special commercial course, in which the students deal largely with the trade and navigation returns of Canada and other countries. I would suggest that the hon. gentleman's department supply the book to the different collegiate institutes.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I do not know how many collegiate institutes there are. I believe they are pretty widely distributed throughout the province of Ontario, and if we distributed the book to these we would have to send it to the corresponding educational establishments in the other provinces. Will the hon. gentleman give me an idea of the number of them, and if we have a sufficient number

of the books on band, I shall be glad to distribute them to these institutions.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I cannot speak for the other provinces, but in the province of Ontario I do not think there would be more than one to each riding.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: If the number were not more than one to every riding of the Dominion we would have a supply sufficient for them, and I would be very glad to see that this was done.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: How many did you issue last year ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: 5,000	were ordered last year.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: How many were distributed to members ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: There is no fixed number. The members who asked for them received, in some cases, as many as ten, but generally four or five.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Was there no rule as to the number ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: There was no special rule, but four or five were usually given each member who wanted them. Many did not ask for them.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
Then those who were a little modest came out rather short. It is well to know that we can have a dozen if we want them.
Mr.! HUGHES (Victoi'ia). Why was not a certain number distributed to each member ? I did not ask for any, how many did I get ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I presume you got none.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Every member should get a certain number, as in the case of other blue-books.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: This is not sent out in the way the blue-books are. It is not published by an order of this House, but by the Department of Agriculture. The other blue-books are published and distributed by the order of the House, but this is published on an entirely different system as it always has been.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: This vote is an order to publish this book, and every member should have one or two sent him, and the hon. minister who refuses to send these out is derelict in his duty.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I got three or four copies, which were all that was available. I would like, to have had some more because a number of the school teachers like to get them.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I am protesting continually when I receive by mail the enormous amount of literature published toy order of this House. This costs the country a great Hon. Mr. FISHER.
many hundreds of thousands of dollars. It is very difficulty to ask a minister to cut down his expenses, when public documents are sent so lavishly about. I get from the Department of Agriculture every year an enormous number of reports, which I am supposed to distribute amongst my agricultural constituents, but except a few dealers in bananas, I do not know of any agriculturalists in my constituency. Each member has stacks of this kind of stuff sent him which he is not able to utilize. My office is filled up with these publications. I have no time to read them nor do I know of any idle people who have. Hundreds of thousands of dollars must be thus unnecessarily expended in almost every department, and a great deal of the matter is published in French. I would like gentlemen on the other side to assist the members of the government in saving half a million dollars in this item. Of course under the same heading comes the enormous expenditure on 1 Hansard.' If you would discontinue the publication of ' Hansard,' you would have shorter speeches and fewer of them, and you could get through an amount of business in two months which now takes four months. A committee should be appointed to take the whole matter into consideration with a view of cutting down the expenditure.
Mr. LaRIVIERE. For the information of my hon. friend I may say that the Joint Committee on Printing of both Houses has appointed a sub-committee to look into those matters. We are getting statistics, and the sub-committee is to report to the Joint Committee, which in its turn will report to the House. I am sorry that the hon. gentleman thought proper to take objection to the publications printed in French.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: That is not what I intended.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I received three or four copies of the Year-book and was very glad indeed to get them. It is a very useful publication for school teachers and much sought after by them. With regard to the printing of the House, I am glad to endorse the remarks of my hon. friend from Centre Toronto (Mr. Brock). I could not cart away all the publications I received and which I do not read. We are furnished with two reports of each department. These are big books, and I find my library growing so that I scarcely have a place to put the stuff. When I cannot use it or give it away, it becomes waste material. Therefore, I think the suggestion of the hon. member is in the right direction, and that by reducing the cost of turning out and distributing these publications we shall be able to affect a considerable saving.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
The Statistical Year-book has been regarded for many years as, one of the most useful publications turned out by the government. I maintain that

it should be in every school of any importance in Canada. I took that position in this House ten years ago and have maintained it every year since. If twice as many copies of this book were sent out and fewer of the trash of question and answer and long-winded stuff of the Agricultural Committee, matter that is being sent out by the ton, but not half of it distributed-and nobody would read it if he got it-the country would be better served, and there would be less drain upon the treasury.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I can hardly allow that statement to go without answer. I believe that the distribution of the evidence taken in the Agricultural Committee is of very great value indeed, particularly when distributed in the form of bulletins as has been done for a few years past. These small pamphlets are read when the larger volume printed at the end of the year would not be so carefully perused. I believe that many members representing agricultural constituencies find a means of distributing these small volumes without taking up a great deal of time. I know I have found no difficulty in getting rid of any that have been sent to me, and 1 am sure that I could dispose of double the quantity.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: You may have mine.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I understand my hon. friend from Centre Toronto (Mr. Brock) to say that I may have his. I should thank him very kindly if he will forward them to my address at Acton. 1 can make good use of them, and I presume he will not require any further reminder. My plan for distributing them is this :	For example, I get,
let us say sixty copies of the evidence of Professor Robertson before the Agricultural Committee. I do these up in parcels containing eight or ten copies each and address them to postmasters at rural points where 1 am satisfied they will take considerable interest in handing them out to persons who call for their mail. It is not necessary to address each one separately. 1 have followed that up by asking the farmers if they have received these bulletins, and have found that they did, proving that the documents went into the hands of people who would make good use of them. I am satisfied that a great deal of information given in the way of question and answer is more readily grasped by the agriculturists than if it were contained in a more closely written volume. I would not like to see a closer limit put upon these publications, for I regard them as very useful and helpful to those to whom they are sent.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I would like to call the attention of the Minister of Agriculture to the attacks made upon him in the House and in the press of the country with regard to the accuracy of publications issued by his department. The minister is responsible for those publications and can-89
not shelter himself behind officers of his department. I notice that he takes considerable credit to himself in the latter portion of his report for the large distribution of this work-I refer to the Statistical Year-book-throughout the country. If this book is not more accurate than some of the newspapers supporting the government-even personal organs of ministers, if all tales be true-have said, the fewer copies of it that are distributed the better. If my hon. friend from South Ontario (Mr. Ross) wants the teachers to know how our country is progressing, he had better not send them the Statistical Year-book, if statements made by members of the Treasury Benches are to be believed. A Minister of the Crown has gone so far as to say that a gentleman who refers to the Statistical Year-book for facts relating to this country is led into a trap. Does the Minister of Agriculture ask us to vote his salary, when be has not a word to say in support of a publication from his department that is thus characterized by one of his own colleagues, and by the press sup-, porting the government of which he is a member ? I expected the minister, when this item came up, to say something about these charges and to defend this publication of his even against the attacks of his colleagues. But we hear no word from him, and are left to guess as best we may whether the attacks are well founded or not. Members of this House have a right to look to a publication sent out by the Minister of Agriculture as a document worthy to be believed ; but, if we are to believe the allegations to which I have referred, this is an absolutely unreliable publication and any hon. gentleman who refers to it and bases an argument upon it is regarded by members of the government as being led into a trap. In other words, the hon. gentleman's colleagues tell him that this book issued by this department is a trap of misinformation to the people of this country. Yet, though he has heard these charges for the last two or three weeks, the minister has not a word to say in the defence of his department or of this publication. Knowing the hon. minister as I do, I would have expected him to be as loyal to his officials as he would expect his officials to he loyal to him. This book does not purport, so far as a considerable part of the information concerned in it is concerned, to be anything more than an estimate. Yet, we do not expect Ministers of the Crown will he in a position to rise in this House and say that gentlemen who refer to this book published by the Minister of Agriculture are being led into a trap. I do not suppose that those who have made .this charge understand how they reflect upon the Minister of Agriculture, and, apparently, the Minister of Agriculture himself does-not understand the seriousness of the charge made against him and against his department. Otherwise when he was asking for $4,000 to publish this work dur-



iug the ensuing year he would have something to- say about the matter.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I must confess frankly that I have never undertaken, as minister, to examine every detail of the information contained in this book, and to verify it. I believe that is the duty of the officers who are entrusted with the work of compiling this book, and the hon. gentleman must know that no Minister of the Crown can be expected to go through the drudgery that such work would enta'il. I regret to say that discoveries have been made of inaccuracies in this book, and of figures which do not agree with each other. I have only to say to the leader of the opposition and to the committee, that I trust such inaccuracies will not take place any more. The Year-book is a compilation from the blue-books which are issued from the various departments, it is -compiled by officers of the department, and it is their duty to see that it is accurate, that the transcription of figures is ' correctly done, and that nothing appears in it at variance with the facts. That such things should appear in it is certainly a reflection upon the department and upon the officers who have charge of the work. 1 realize that as political head of the department, I must shoulder the responsibility for the mistakes.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Do I understand from the hon. gentleman that his officers are not competent to prepare this book ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I have always supposed them to be competent, and I still suppose them to be competent. If they do not carry out their duty it will be my duty to see that they do so in future.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I would not have it understood that I am opposed to the publication of the agricultural report. I happen to be a member of that committee, and I find its work extremely interesting and instructive. I am sure the reports which go out from that committee must be interesting and instructive to the farmers. I find great pleasure in distributing those reports, and I find the farmers receive them gladly. It is some of the other reports which do not seem to be of interest to anybody. I am sorry to learn from the discussion which has occurred to-night that there should be anything wrong with the Year-book. I think we should have such a Year-book, and that it should go into the hands of every teacher in this country for use in the schools. I think it would be a good move to put it into the hands of every teacher, showing the growth of the country and the growth of its business.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I do not want my hon. friend to understand that I am reflecting upon the Year-book in any way. I quoted from it, and I believe that what I quoted was correct. I have no fault to find Mr. BORDEN (Halifax).
with it at all. I was calling the attention of the Minister of Agriculture to the reflections which have been cast upon this book not from this side but from the other Side of the House, and from the Liberal press of this country. The only thing that surprised me was that the Minister of Agriculture did not see fit, after the matter was brought to his attention, to make some defence of his own publication while the item was passing.
Hon. Mr. ItOSS (Victoria, N.S.) My objection to the Year-book is its shabby appearance. I do not call it a Year-book at all, it is not bound, and I consider that a book giving information of the Dominion of Canada should have a respectable appearance. There is a Year-book published by the colony of New Zealand for the year 1901, which contains twenty times the information that our Year-book contains. There is nothing in our Year-book but dry details and figures which very few men in this House or out of it will ever read. The New Zealand Year-book is beautiful and interesting, and contains 'information of great interest and value concerning that colony, and I would like to see our Year-book made something like it.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I am sorry the Minister of Agriculture neglected our esteemed friend in the distribution of these beautiful volumes such as I hold in my hand. I am surprised that the member for Victoria N.S. (Hon. Mr. Ross) has not seen this beautiful volume; I hope he has no objection to it because it is red. I do not put such confidence in our Year-book as the leader of the opposition does. I confess that I rarely quote from it, or rarely take any information from it without first verifying it. I regret to be obliged to say that there are two or three tables in that Year-book that should not be in it. I believe there are tables put in there for a political purpose. When hon. gentlemen sat on this side of the House years ago, they accused the Conservative party of compiling this Year-book with a political object. Well, if they were guilty at that time, I do not think the hon. gentlemen are less guilty to-day. I will draw the attention of the minister to one table in this book which I hope will be amended next year, because there is not a word of truth in it from top to bottom. It would be unfortunate to place such a book in the hands of our school children. I call attention to the table on page 481 of the Year-book for 1899, which I got from the library a few moments ago. It is a table giving the standing of the different provinces and of their debts. On page 478 it first gives the provincial debts of the provinces of Quebec, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Manitoba, British Columbia, and Prince Edward Island, but leaves out Ontario.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: That has no debt.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
Evidently these gentlemen have been reading this book, and

consequently they are utterly ignorant of tlie state of the finances in the province of Ontario. Now, we have, a.t page 481, a statement of the surpluses from 1882 to 1899 also giving a statement of the railway liability payable in the future extending over forty years. It gives the Railway liability in each particular year of the province of Ontario. I shall take the year 1899, where it is stated that our railway liability is $1,962,903. Now, I take the budget speech of the hon. Prime Minister of Ontario (Mr. Ross) given a few months ago in which he states that the railway liability in January, was $3,510,790.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: What year ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Up to the end of 1901. There is just the difference between the two years. The figures have increased somewhat. I am not quite sure that there was an increase in 1900 or 1901, but I beg to say that there is very little difference indeed.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Do I understand that that is the budget speech for this year ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Yes.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Well, then that would be up to the end of 1901, and the statistical tables published in 1S99 would be for the year 1898, so that you would have three years.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: No, the table I read from this year is for the year 1899. Now, the hon. gentleman (Mr. Fraser) need not try to mix it. There would be a difference of possibly two years, but that would be the fullest extent of the difference. But, of course, there could not be a difference by any means of $2,000,000. I do not think it exceeded $500,000, if it exceeded $200,000. While we have Mr. Ross stating that the railway debt at the end of 1901 was $3,510,790, the Year-book places it at the end of 1S99 at $1,962,000. The commission sat since then, as an hon. gentleman suggests, but I do not know that it would make any material difference in the figures. 1 think they discovered that the debt was just about as large as it had been understood to be. It does not affect the matter that I object to. I will take another column because the object appears to me to be to show that Ontario has no debt at all. It is really the intention to convey that impression to the mind of the young reader in the public school when we all know that Ontario has a debt of nearly $6,000,000. There is $1,815,000 due the Dominion government, and we are paying interest from the province of Ontario to the Dominion on that sum of 4 and 5 per cent, a pretty high rate of interest to exact.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: There Is something on the other side of the account.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Yes, but it is the wrong way. 1 will discuss the question that the hon. Minister of Finance referred to, in a moment ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I do not want to debate it with my hon. friend.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
Leaving the matter, then, of the debt, which, I understand is nearly $6,000,000, I think it is very wrong in publishing a table of this kind to convey the impression that it is under $2,000,000. Another heading is : ' Surplus of assets .over liabilities,' and it is put down that in 1899 we have $2,250,932 of assets over all liabilities. Now, every man who is familiar with the financial history of the province of Ontario knows perfectly well that there is not a dollar of surplus and that for many years there has not been. That is a well known fact. A commission was appointed to try and find out this surplus a year or two ago, and when the commission reported, they said nothing about the surplus. However, that did not satisfy the Prime Minister of Ontario. He wanted a surplus and he asked an accountant in the city of Toronto by letter, to see if he could not find one. No doubt, the accountant was well paid for it and he furnished a report in which he actually did find a surplus. I have the report under my hand. I have the report of the royal commission, and it is put in a very peculiar way. The appendix to the report is put under the same cover as the report of the royal commission and went forth to the country actually as a government print and as a part of the report of the royal commission, when it was a well known fact that not a word of it was certified to by the commissioners. The commissioners made their report on the 13th of February, 1900, and the other work was undertaken on the 27th of March, when the Prime Minister wrote a letter to the accountant asking him to investigate this matter. No doubt he found a surplus but he did it by including an asset which was manufactured out of a subsidy that this government granted in 1884 to the province of Ontario, of $142,414, and by capitalizing it at 5 per cent, he made an item of $2,848,000, which he placed among the assets. That sum, however, being in excess of the sur-' plus that the government claimed by some $300,000, shows that instead of having a surplus of assets, they actually had no surplus at all, save that obtained by capitalizing a subsidy that nobody acknowledges as money, and which the hon. Minister of Finance himself, says the province of Ontario has not an unconditional right to, or, to use his own words :
I do not think your government have any unconditional right to demand this money from the Dominion.
They capitalized the sum representing the subsidy paid year after year by this government to the province of Ontario, and to

which capitalized sum the hen. Minister of Finance here says the Ontario government have no unconditional right to.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: My hon. friend might read that letter a little farther in all fairness.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I will read the whole letter if the hon. gentleman desires it.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I do not desire it; it has been printed fifty times.
Mr. HENDERSON, (reading.)
I do not think your government have any unconditional right to demand this money from the Dominion. There are certain limitations provided by the statutes; hut no doubt if you desired to obtain the money you could easily comply with these conditions!
We all know that. Ontario can comply with the conditions, surrender the subsidy and take the larger sum, but Ontario does not want to do that. The province of Ontario might in the same way sell out any other asset that it had. I fail to see that there is anything gained by my reading the hon. gentleman's letter. This, I assume, is only the hon. minister's opinion, which he gave in order to help the Prime Minister at Toronto on the eve of an election at a very critical time. I am not going to say that the hon. Minister of Finance overstated what he believed to be correct, but I confess there are other men in the country who have given this matter careful consideration and they are directly of an opposite opinion to that of the lion. Minister of Finance in respect to that sum of money. It is simply capitalizing a sum of money that was granted by this government to the province of Ontario, and which this government is compelled to pay year after year to the province of Ontario.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: So long as Ontario wants it.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
So long as Ontario wants it, and until this parliament authorizes this government to pay It over and until the provincial legislature of Ontario authorizes that government to receive it and in doing that they wipe out the subsidy. In that same way they might wipe out any other asset they have. There is not a dollar available to-day for the purpose of meeting the liabilities of the province. I therefore say, that this table is misleading and that it should be eliminated from the Year-book. It is too bad that our young minds should be led away with the idea that we have a large surplus in Ontario when we know that we are paying interest on a debt of $6,000,000, and that we have not a dollar of surplus over and above our actual liabilities. I will not analyse the contents of the Yearbook further, but I confess that if I ever happen to quote statistics from this book,
I am always careful to verify them by other departmental records.

SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: It is unfair that the hon. gentleman (Mr. Henderson) should take up the time of this parliament in discussing the finances of the province of Ontario, with the intention of affecting the result in a local election which is about to take place.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I rise to a point of order. The hon. member (Mr. Flint) has impuned the motives of another hon. member in this House.
The MINISTER Or FINANCE. He did not attribute an improper motive. It is not a crime to try to influence an election.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
In order to save time, I will withdraw the expression, whether it is parliamentary or not. This whole question of the Ontario surplus was discussed last election and the argument of the supporters of the local government was well sustained by the facts. A careful examination of Ontario finances from an economical standpoint will show that the statement in the Yearbook is substantially correct. If my hon. friend wishes to show that the Year-book is incorrect I do not wish to deprive him of the pleasure, but he should not take up the time of this House in providing provincial campaign literature. He was entirely out of order in dealing with the Ontario finances. The Year-book in the main is correct, but all people are liable to make mistakes, and mistakes do sometimes occur in the Yearbook without any particular fault except perhaps a lack of care in due preparation of the figures. I have often had occasion to find fault with the manner of the compilation of the Year-book. I think the book might be made more interesting and useful, but I have no particular objection as to the correctness of the figures. The suggestion of the hon. member for East Toronto (Mr. Brock) as to the enormous expense of publishing and circulating the blue-books is worthy of our attention. I am glad to know, as stated by the hon. member for Proven-cher (Mr. LaRiviere) that a sub-committee of the Printing Committee is considering that whole subject with the view of adopting a plan by which a great deal of money could be saved to the country. I would suggest to that sub-committee that a careful list be made of those who receive these publications. The list has been altogether too large in the past. Ex-members of parliament who may have been here only a short time and who care nothing about these things have these publications sent to them for years and years after they have ceased to be members of this House.
Mr. LaRIVIERE. Only in case they apply for them.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
The list should be carefully revised and made as small as it can be. I would suggest that a circular should be issued containing the names of all the publications and asking that those entitled to

receive them should mark off those which they desire to receive, so that those which do not interest them would not be sent. In that way thousands of dollars would be saved. I am pleased to get as many publications as the average member of parliament, but a great part of those which I do receive are useless to me and to others. They have the disadvantage that they cannot he burned in the furnace because they block it up, and it is often difficult to know what to do with them. There are, of course, the bound volumes which can be put into private libraries or donated to public libraries and they are useful. I think. Sir, that the remarks of the Minister of Agriculture covered the whole ground in regard to the Year-book. If errors have crept in through carelessness or inadvertence they will be corrected. Personally, I would like to see the Year-book published under a different system in the future, but the minister and his colleagues will no doubt come to a decision upon that. Be that as it may, I do not think that the committee should have its time taken up discussing the finances of Ontario.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I dissent from the sentiments expressed by the hon. gentleman (Mr. Flint). There is no thoughtful member of this House who will say that he can dispense with any of the departmental reports. They are the public records of the country. The hon. gentleman will see that he gets two unbound copies, one of which is supposed to be used during the session of parliament and the other he can very easily dispose of because there are many intelligent persons in the country who are always very glad to get them. The hon. gentleman says he has difficulty in burning them, but I ask him now if on reflection he will say that he can dispense with a single public document that is printed by order of this parliament.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I hope my hon. friend does not imagine that I intimated that they should be dispensed with. I merely suggested that the list of those who receive them should be carefully revised, and that those to whom books are sent should be asked to state what they want and what they do not want.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
The hon. member knows that that is an impossibility. The Printing Committee provide for the publication of a certain number of these documents. If there are some members who do not care for the sessional papers, the committee are not able to determine in advance whether they will take them or not. If the hon. gentleman had the control of this matter he would find himself at the close of the year in a complete difficulty in regard to the distribution, though I have no doubt that some saving might be made in the printing. Coming back to this much-abused Year-book, it does not pretend to be more than a sort of compilation of the public
records, and if they have been in any sense false, it would not do for the compiler of the Year-book to undertake to correct them. For this reason the statistician is not to blame for having stated that there was no debt in the province of Ontario, because he simply took the public records as he found them. You would not expect a public official to undertake to correct from his own bat any public documents. I do not think it is a fair charge to bring against the Minister of Agriculture to say that this Year-book is inaccurate, beyond this, that he has sat in his place and has permitted attacks to be made upon it in this House for party purposes. On the whole, it is a reliable and very satisfactory work, and it is not fair to have it go out that there are immense inaccuracies in it. Its compiler would be more than human if no errors occurred in it, but there are none to seriously impair the value of the work.
iMr. HUGHES (Victoria). I was very much surprised to hear the hon. member for Yarmouth speak of curtailing the distribution of one or two of these publications to members of parliament or ex-members of parliament. Who are better fitted or take greater interest in watching the proceedings of parliament than ex-members of parliament ? I said a moment ago that a good deal of money was wasted in the distribution of these agricultural reports. I am satisfied that it cannot be carried on as it was a year or two ago, when the evidence, which could all be compressed into four or five pages of common sense, was sent out in books of 200 or 300 pages and distributed in tons throughout the country. A farmer would never sit down to read these books. This system, I presume, has been discontinued.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: No, they are printed by the order of the House. The Department of Agriculture has nothing whatever do with that.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: It would pay this country to have some intelligent sessional clerk, if such can be found, condense the whole thing into a nice little concise volume of twenty pages, and distribute' that. I think there is a great deal of money wasted, not only in connection with this item, but in connection with the printing of parliament. Very many reports are ordered to be distributed when only two or three copies are wanted ; and some of these sessional clerks who are standing around and getting in everybody's way instead of attending to their own business, might be engaged to strike off two or three copies on the typewriter for those who want them.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
With reference to the number of reports of the Committee on Agriculture, the hon. gentleman has exaggerated. I have been on that committee for a number of years, and I understand

how these reports are given out to be distributed. No report of 300 or 400 pages is distributed in large numbers ; but the House recommended the printing of a certain number of copies of the summary reports to be given to members of parliament for distribution, and my experience is that members representing rural constituencies have applied to members representing city constituencies to give them a portion of their number for distribution in their constituencies. We have had many controversies in the committee on this subject, the difficulty having been to get the House to order enough to satisfy the needs of the committee. With- regard to the Year-book, X think it is regrettable to see one minister of the Crown getting up and discrediting a publication got out by another department. If we cannot rely on the official reports, what can we rely on ? If they are not reliable, the minister at the head of the department ought to be held responsible.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: As one member who I am sure would like to say something on the subject of the Year-book is absent through illness this evening, I would suggest that the minister allow this item to stand and take up some other items.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: This item has been already once before the House. If my hon. friend did not wish to discuss it, he should have said so when it was first called. But after we have discussed it so long, I do not think we ought to postpone it.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I presume the hon. minister will have no objection to discuss the subject on another item.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
Not at all.
General statistics, $3,200.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: That is the item out of which the compilation of the Year-book is paid. There are some extra clerks paid out of this vote, and the balance is available for any statistical work.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I would like to ask the minister if he is going to employ this ubiquitous gentleman who sells books, writes for the magazines and obtains land values. I refer to Mr. Washington. I am not disposed to quarrel with useful expenditure, but we have a return made by Mr. Washington which is absolutely worthless: Mr. Washington is a gentleman who has been taken care of by the Minister of Agriculture.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
