maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: He said he was not a Liberal but voted with the Liberal party. He solemnly swore he was not a Liberal but a free trader. This is an absolute waste of money.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Mr. Washington was doing, in the course of the last two or three years, certain investigations and statistical work for which he was paid out of this vote: The report is on the Table of the House. He made some investigations into the selling value of rural lands, and the trend of rise and fall in the value of such lands. The work has extended over the past three years and when at work he is paid out of this fund. He has not worked in this fiscal year at all, and consequently has not been paid out of this fund.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Who are paid out of this fund ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: None except the clerks engaged under Mr. Johnston in compilation.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: We ought to put the whole sum fairly chargeable to the Statistical Year-book in one item so that we might know from year to year what it costs.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The vote for the Statistical Year-book is simply fpr printing it. The book is printed in the Bureau and the $4,000 is all paid to the Bureau for printing it.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The hon. gentleman says that Mr. Washington received no pay for the current year.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I do not think so.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Then he was paid last year.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Yes.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: His report must have been made to the department last year. How does it come that no report but Mr. Washington's appears in the Year-book ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The portion of this vote is to pay ordinary clerks in the department, a part of the staff engaged on the Year-book and any other statistical work that may be given out, and a portion is employed to pay anybody else who may be doing statistical work.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Then, we understand that Mr. Washington gets paid for making land values ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Well, that may be one way of putting it. but I would not put it that way. What I said was that he was paid for investigating land values.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Many are employed in my department who are called temporary clerks. They were there before I took charge, and are practically permanent officers. Seme have been in the department for 15 years, some perhaps, for even 20 years.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Why not make them permanent ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I have not disturbed the order of affairs that I found in existence. It would require a considerable change in the organization of the department, and I have not seen fit to undertake that any more than did my predecessors. I have not the names of the clerks at the moment, but I can get them for the hon. gentleman. For his satisfaction, I may tell him that there is not a single one paid out of this vote that was not there when I took charge of the department.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I think that only Mr. Johnson and two clerks were working there when the hon. gentleman took office.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I think the hon. gentleman (Mr. Ingram) is mistaken. I can get the list of clerks.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Some other time will do.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I do not think the committee is disposed to accept as final the hon. minister's statement that he will consider whether he will retain Mr. Washington as a fixture upon the service of this country. It is not pleasant to be forced to state in the House the opinion one holds of one in Mr. Washington's position. But when a man is paid hundreds of dollars-running into thousands by this time-and yet does not hesitate to state his conclusion and put it in writing that during the exact year when the Liberals were in power, the hard times had the effect of enhancing the land values, and that they had the very opposite effect when the Conservatives were in power, what are we to think of the value of the employment by government of such a man ? I have no hesitation in saying that no one but a lunatic would base such a statement upon the evidence produced by Mr. Washington. I, for one, am not disposed to let this item pass until we have some declaration from the minister that he has at least made up his mind to discontinue a work that is utterly useless and, indeed, disgraceful. If the hon. minister is ready to stand sponsor and godfather for
work of that kind, and cannot make up his mind whether to discontinue it or not, I, for one, propose that the item shall not pass until he can tell the House what he intends to do. I do not wish to stand in the way of the item passing, but I think the committee is entitled to some declaration on the subject. This side of the House can make up their minds, if the hon. minister cannot.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: It seems to me that the hon. gentleman (Mr. Clancy) is unduly violent over a matter which does not necessarily call for such strong language. As to the report made by Mr. Washington, until we have had copies of It printed and in our hands to study, it is impossible for us to come to a conclusion concerning it. That such an inquiry is absurd and valueless, I think has not been proved, and cannot be proved. That there is such a thing as rise and fall of land values in various portions of the country, and that this may be caused by different occurrences, will hardly be denied. But the opinion of the minister, in which I concur, is that to carry on that inquiry throughout the Dominion upon the scale upon which Mr. Washington started out, would take a long time and a great deal of money. I, for one, as a member of the committee do not see that we could reasonably ask the House to vote the sum necessary for such a work. But I do not think it fair to discuss Mr. Washington's report until it is in our hands, and. it seems to me that the language used by the hon. gentleman is not justified under the circumstances.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Where do we find recorded the salaries paid to this man Washington ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Mr. Washington has no salary, and he has not been paid anything by the department in the current year. This item is for general statistics for next year and, so far, I have formed no plan for paying Mr. Washington out of this item. When he was paid, he was paid out of this item in last year's vote and the vote of the year before.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Was he paid out of any other department or any other fund ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Not that I am aware of.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
It seems to me clear that if Mr. Washington was paid out of this vote, an improper use was made of the money. Judging by his report, Mr. Washington is only a political jobber, a land valuator getting up the case for the Reform party. The sum and substance of his work is an effort to show that the land went down in value when the Conservative party were in power and went up when the Reform party came into power. And I think

the hon. member for Bothwell ( Mr. Clancy) was quite right in saying that the data Mr. Washington gave could not be used as a basis for his conclusions by any one other than a lunatic. He had nothing reliable to go upon, and yet, for the purpose of his party he was willing to make this report. And we pay him under the head of general statistics. I say he is improperly paid if paid out of this item, and he is improperly employed If employed at all.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I wish to say a word to my hon. friend from Yarmouth (Mr. Flint). That hon. gentleman seems to have an abhorrence of public records and to have forsworn the use of them. This report of which we are speaking has been on the Table for a month, and if the hon. gentleman was inclined to be informed he has had the opportunity. Yet, though he has not read this report, he does not hesitate to rise and defend it. Now if the hon. gentleman appeals to the Minister of Agriculture he will put him in possession of that within two minutes.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I think the hon. gentleman has the manuscript of that report in his pocket.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Not at all, the manuscript is in the possession of Mr. Polkinghorne, I have not had it in my pocket at all. The hon. gentleman should have been informed before he made the statement. I repeat that Mr. Washington is a pensioner on the department, 'the Minister of Agriculture says he has not been paid anything during the current year. The hon. gentleman knows that besides being paid for this job, he has been engaged in the census department for a considerable time, he is in fact a man that must be taken care of. When he is not there he is going through the department selling books. The hon. gentleman's own department has bought books from him, every department has bought books from him; he is a perfect nuisance, if I am forced to use such language. That he should be paid out of the public funds of Canada to make up a record of what he calls land values for the use of the intelligent people of this country, is a perfect outrage. It is curious to see liow he arrives at the difference in land values. He tells us that he does not take into consideration any improvements made on the land. The truth is that Mr. Washington has disclosed that his report is utterly worthless, Yet hon. gentlemen will no doubt later on use^ that report and say that during the period the Tories were in power land values went down, and during the period the Liberals were in power they went up. I say a man who will commit himself to a statement of that kind unrebuked is past redemption.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Why didn't you rebuke him the other day when you liad him under cross-examination ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Perhaps I had a good deal better manners than my hon. friend, because, having the opportunity, I would not use it. I was not disposed to take advantage of my position to say unkind things to this man, because I hoped at least that the Minister of Agriculture and hon. gentlemen opposite would put an end to the l'arce.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I would say it to his face rather than behind his back.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: My hon. friend and his friends have brought this upon Mr. Washington. The Minister of Agriculture evidently thinks that Mr. Washington is a very valuable man, and that he cannot possibly part with him. Why cannot the hon. gentleman admit that the whole thing is a farce V Surely hds own friends do not sympathize with the' attitude he has taken this evening ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The hon. gentleman evidently is not very well satisfied with the outcome of the investigation that has been carried on by Mr. Washington. Mr. Washington undertook to investigate facts, not a theory, not a policy, or anything of the kind, but facts in regard to the sales of land in certain counties, which were picked out for the purpose of investigation, through a certain number of years. The facts show that during certain periods land seemed to go down in value, because it sold for less than it brought earlier during those periocl)s. In other periods the land seemed to be rising in value because it sold for a higher price at each successive sale.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Where did he get that information ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: From the registry books of the counties which he examined.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: How did you get that information ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: From his report, and from the details on which he based his report. He based his conclusions on figures in, a multitude of cases, where he found that on one occasion a certain property was sold for a certain sum and on a subsequent occasion it was sold for a higher, or a lower price. Mr. Washington's investigation shows that during certain years there was a steady decrease in prices, and In certain other years there was an Increase in prices obtained for the same properties. It happened unfortunately for the hon. gentlemen opposite that there was a very marked difference since the present government came into power, and that a little while afterwards lands in the rural districts began to increase in value. During the period before the present government came into power lands steadily decreased in value. That is what nettles the hon. gentleman. If Mr. Washington's investigation had told in the other

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: direction, I have no doubt the hon. gentleman would have thought Mr. Washington a heaven-born genius, but as it is, he finds Mr. Washington is something very bad indeed.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: It is evident from what we hear this evening that this gentleman has taken a great deal of unnecessary trouble to go through the registry books and find out at what prices lands in particular localities have been sold. The value of land, as every one knows, is to be found in the value of its products, the value of the wheat for instance. To find the value of wheat you have only to consult the Liverpool market from time to time. The value of land, like everything else, is measured by what it produces. The employment of this gentleman to go through the country and examine registry books in various counties is a most ridiculous waste of money, and must have been done, not for statistial purposes, but for the purpose of bolstering up the pretensions of hon. gentlemen opposite to be the saviours of the country. As to the value of wheat, or the price of any other product of the land, no one pretends that this government or any other government has anything to do with it. The value of timber land is measured by the value of the lumber that it produces. You can always get those statistics without the employment of a man like Mr. Washington to go through the country and examine the registry books. When gentlemen like Mr. Washington start out on a job of that kind they always know what you want theni to do, and they are prepared to keep at it as long as the salary is forthcoming. I really think the Minister of Agriculture should be ashamed of this whole business.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The hon. gentleman was asked on the 25th of February, this question :

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The hon. minister says that the inspiration to appoint such an officer came from himself. As it was he who inspired the idea, he must have known who this gentleman was and where he came from. Did he come from the hon. gentleman's own riding.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
No, he did not. I never knew the gentleman until I met him here at Ottawa and do not know where he came from.
Then the minister says further :

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
Mr. Washington is a gentleman who has been engaged for years in statistical investigation. When I first met him we had a discussion on statistical work. I believe he was at one time in the press gallery, but I did not Inquire particularly into his antecedents.
How docs the hon. gentleman know that if he never knew the gentleman until he met him here at Ottawa ? Then my hon. friend (Mr. Bennett) asks :
Was he on the Montreal ' Herald '?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I do not think he ever was connected with the Montreal ' Herald,' and I cannot remember who introduced
him to me, hut I have known him a good marry years and have frequently discussed statistical work with him.
These three answers do not corroborate each other very well. Now, look at the wonderful work this gentleman did. When the hon. minister was asked where he employed this man his answer was :
I think he went to three counties in Ontario, to one in Quebec, and to one or two in the maritime provinces.
I doubt whether he did come into Ontario with that small expense account of $54.07. The minister proceeds :
I know he was in Prince Edward Island, and I think he examined a county in Nova Scotia.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Does he state that ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: That is what the hon. minister states, and yet we have been told that the valuable work of this man shows a wonderful decrease in land values under the Conservative regime and a wonderful increase during the time that hon. gentlemen have been in power. Then we were told by the hon. minister to-night that this man is paid out of the $3,200. He was paid $722.31 for his salary and $54.67 for his travelling expenses. I see that he has been engaged in the statistical department, for which we are paying $4,000 in one instance and $3,200 in another instance. We have the right to have that gentleman's report included in the Statistical Year-book.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
No, no ; for heaven's sake no.
. Mr. INGRAM. If it has any value at all it should be placed in there, and the hon. gentleman should assume responsibility for it and not come down to this House and lay it on the Table. Not many hon. gentlemen in this House have any opportunity of reading it. If he does statistical work his work should be put into the report, so that we could see it. and if his employment is not justifiable, then, the sooner this man is discharged the better.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: He has evidently been getting up a campaign document.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I think so. The other evening the hon. member for Lanark (Mr. Haggart) introduced a book, and probably if its pages were carefully perused we would find the report of Mr. Washington in it. As to the value of land this gentleman seems to make out an increased value since hon. gentlemen opposite came into .power. In my district land has gone up very materially, but it is only in one or two spots where government buildings are erected and where friends of the government get an increased profit. I have no doubt that my hon. friend from London (Mr. Hyman) finds that values have gone up a little. In the county of Elgin land values in the matter of government purchases, have gone up from something like $80 to $300, so that

since the government came into power there has been an increase of abont 200 per cent.
Mr. BORDEN (Halifax), l would like to say that if this gentleman, Mr. Washington, about whom I know nothing, pursued the method of investigation that has been mentioned by the lion. Minister of Agriculture, the results must- certainly be very valuable. He has gone, the minister says, through the registry offices and investigated the land values there. I believe there has been an investigation of that kind in the province of Nova Scotia.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: In Prince Edward Island and in Ontario.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I thought it was stated that he had investigated Nova Scotia as well.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: No.	[DOT]

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Why has my province been deprived of the services of this gentleman ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: We have not had him long enough to go there.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Well, I will require a full explanation of why my province has been deprived of the services of this gentleman before this item is passed. It is one of the most scandalous attempts to impose on Nova Scotia that I ever heard of. However, for my present purpose, it does not make very much difference about Nova Scotia. I do not suppose deeds are prepared differently in Prince Edward Island from the way in which they are prepared in Nova Scotia. I do not know whether they are prepared differently in Ontario or not. I know that in Nova Scotia in not 50 per cent of the cases is the consideration price correctly stated in the deed of conveyance.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
It is in Quebec.
Mr. BORi->GN (Halifax). Well, the hon. gentleman should have ascertained something about the other provinces before he made any statement as to this gentleman's method of investigation. In thousands of cases, to my own knowledge, in the province of Nova Scotia, in which large transactions have taken place, the sum of one dollar has been mentioned as the consideration.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Would that be in the case of farm lands ? That would be simply in the sale of land to some corporation or the passing of property between relatives.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: And also in the sale of farm lands in the province of Nova Scotia. Personally, when I purchased a property which I own there, the consideration which was stated was one dollar.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Probably that was the real value ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: My hon. friend (Mr. McCarthy) is welcome to that idea if he desires to entertain it.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: It shows the increase in the value of land.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Since the government came into power.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: That does not prove it has not increased in value.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: In many eases the consideration w'hich is stated in Novft Scotia is one dollar. Now does this gentleman obtain any valuable information by looking at deeds of that character ? Yet, according to the hon. Minister of Agriculture the only way in which he has pursued liis inquiries is by resorting to the registry offices. Would the hon. gentleman state whether in different counties he has made these investigations exhaustive as to farm lands?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Yes, in every instance where there were two sales of the same property.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: That is not an answer to the question. Dees he take all the farm land in any particular county and go through it ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Yes. He takes every case where there are two sales of the same property within the period which he is investigating, so as to see whether there has been a rise or a fall in the value of that property.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Does my hon. friend mean that he takes a period of say twenty or twenty-five years and investigates every sale of farm property in a particular county during that period ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Yes.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: A great many of the sales that take place in the province of Ontario at the present time are the sales of land held under mortgage. A portion of the mortgage is paid off and the purchaser agrees to pay a certain consideration and assume the mortgage.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: That is recited in the deed.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: How does any person know how much of the mortgage is unpaid ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: It is registered.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Not at all.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Mortgages are all registered.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
Yes, the mortgage is registered but until the discharge of the

whole mortgage there is nothing in the registry office to show how much remains to be paid. There is usually a portion of the mortgage paid before the property is sold and when the property is sold, because the companies are pushing for payment, the party who purchases the property agrees to assume the mortgage. You go to the registry office and you can find no trace there of the actual value of that land, or what it has changed hands for except for that.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: As there seems to be some doubt in the minds of gentlemen opposite as to the increase in farm values in recent years, I wish to say that I know of two farms in my own neighbourhood that were sold eight or ten years ago, and again sold within the last six months. About ten years ago one of these farms was sold for $10,000, and the purchaser built on it a new barn, costing about $15,000. That farm was sold within the last six months for $13,500. Another farm was sold eight or ten years ago for $6,500, and it was resold about four months ago for $7,500, or $1,000 more, with out any improvements having been made. These are two cases in my own experience.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: (Translation.) I was surprised when I heal'd some hon. gentlemen say that for the hon. minister to have employed a man who was throughly competent and having technical knowledge, to make up a record of land values throughout the several provinces of the Dominion, was an outrage and a farce. Now, in the province of Quebec, from which I come, and in my own riding, for instance, farmers do not raise wheat, and they depend altogether for their revenue on dairying ; and such being the case, I should like the hon. member for Toronto Centre (Mr. Brock) to tell me how he would manage to measure the value of farm lands in my riding, if it be true, as he stated, that to find out the value of lands in this country, you have to consult the London market ailone.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I am sorry to see hon. gentlemen opposite obstructing these estimates and in both languages. Is it the intention of the minister to employ Washington during the next fiscal pear ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I have made no plans for it.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: If such were the intention. I would move that this item be reduced by the amount of his salary. Who paid his travelling expenses of $52, travelling all the way from Prince Edward Island to Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Quebec and Ontario ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: All the expenses he charged were paid by the department.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: How much were they ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: 1 cannot tell you off-hand.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The question before us is that the service rendered by this man was utterly useless to the country. In order to show the character of the man I may mention that he stated without a blush on his solemn oath that he worked on Sundays, and of course he was paid for it. How much has Mr. Washington been paid since he commenced, and how long has he been working in the department ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I find from the Auditor General's Report that last year he was paid $285. As far as I can see he has been paid altogether about $1,000. He commenced I think in 1897 or 1898.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Better let the item stand until we get definite information.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: No.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: If this man were employed to get valuable statistics I could understand the expenditure, but when he came to the province of Ontario he had in the report of the Bureau of Industries, the value of land from year to year as published by the friends of this government. If he desired the only reliable information at his hand he could have obtained it* there, but he paid no attention to it and his statistics are worthless. What is the matter with the hon. member for North Simcoe ? He appears to be amused, as*he always is, about something that is of no importance to any one but himself.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Don't worry about me. Mr. SPROULE. The hon. gentleman should know that he is in the House of Commons. We have a right to discharge our duties without these senseless interruptions. The sooner his constituents know the way he conducts himself the better. I say that these statistics are about on a par with the supposed statistics alleged to have been collected by Mr. Cote and his friends in regard to the census of 1891. They are got for political purposes and for nothing else and public money spent in that way is misapplied.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The hon. member (Mr. Clancy) has said that this gentleman worked on Sunday. The question was put to Mr. Washington if he was authorized to work on Sunday, and his answer was ' No.' May I ask the minister if that gentleman is emiiloyed in the department now.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: No.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I may tell the hon. member for Grey (Mr. Sproule) that the reason of my amusement was that he stated that the information published by the Bureau of Statistics in Ontario was authentic. That statement coming from him

amused us. He tried to withdraw from that position and he said it was authentic at least so far as government information could be correct. Does he now say that the information published by the Bureau of Industries in Ontario is in his opinion correct.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I want the hon. gentleman to understand that he is not in court nor am I here to be cross-ques/tioned. He may assume a good deal as a certain class of lawyers do, but fortunately I am not under his control now.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: This man Washington has been here since 1897. What other reports has he made ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: He has only made one report.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I object to the minister sitting on his seat when answering a question.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Would the hon. gentleman like to see me sit anywhere else ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I would now ask the minister how it is that this officer has oiily handed in one report in so many years ? What has he been doing in the past years ? Has he been engaging in elections ?
The * MINISTER OF AGRICULTURE. The hon. gentleman is asking a question and then answering it himself. Mr. Washington did not hand in his report until his work was finished.- When it was brought to a conclusion he handed in his report.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The hon. gentleman has not given us the information which I asked for a moment ago, namely, when Mr. Washington began his duties, and how much he was paid each year up to the time he concluded that report.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Mr. Washington commenced his work, I think, in the year 1897, and he has been working off and on occasionally since that time. I cannot give the hon. gentleman the information as to how much he has been paid each year. I could send to the library and get the Auditor General's Report for each year, in which, as the hon. gentleman knows, that information lias been published, and he can get it very easily.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I understood the minister to say that he is not employed by him. Is he employed in any other department ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Not that I am aware of.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Was he not employed in the Census Department lately ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: He was. He resigned from the census about two months ago.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I would like to ask the hon. gentleman if these people are still em-Mr. McCarthy
ployed in the department : Mr. Watts, Mr. Monroe, Miss Ross and Mr. Lepage.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Yes, they are still employed. They have been employed there ever since I have been in the office.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Are there any others besides these ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I do not know of any others.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The hon. gentleman said last year that there were two others.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: If the hon. gentleman will turn to the Auditor General's report, he will find on page D-4 the salaries, and on page D-13 General Statistics and other expenditures, in which he will find the payments to Mr. Washington.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Mr. Washington could not have been paid out of this $3,200 last year, because the minister otherwise accounted for the whole amount.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Will the hon. gentleman give the committee the date when Mr. Washington commenced his services, and where he was making his investigations in 1899, in 1900, and in a portion of 1901, which Is not included in this report ? The reason I ask for this is that the hon. gentleman stated that Mr. Washington's report as laid on the Table did not contain all the information.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I should be glad to give the hon. gentleman every figure and table. I did not lay these on the Table, but they are in the department, and if the hon. gentleman wants them, I will bring them, though I do not think that either he or I would be willing to go through them.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I am afraid the hon. gentleman is making it necessary for us to insist on the information, no matter how unpleasant it may be for the committee. If the minister has now found himself in the unpleasant position of being required to furnish the information on which we may judge of this gigantic work which he says is going on, I think it is well that we should have some information to guide us more definitely on that point. The hon. gentleman will recognize, I am sure, that it is a very reasonable request that he should put the committee in possession of that information, and I do not think he should expect the item to pass until he does.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I think the hon. gentleman is entirely unreasonable in asking that all the figures from which certain conclusions are drawn should be laid before the House. He might as well ask for every customs paper on which the trade and navigation returns are

based to be laid before the House. The hon. gentleman knows that every report is based on millions of figures and statements obtained from officers all over the country.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The two cases are not at all similar. In the one case the figures are those of a gentleman who had wormed himself into the affections of the Minister of Agriculture ; in the other case the figures are obtained from regular official documents. I ask the hon. gentleman if he intends to continue Mr. Washington in office ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I said I have not made up my mind.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: It is about time the hon. gentleman did.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I will do that when ready.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The hon. gentleman will find it convenient some time to make up his mind. He had better let the item stand until he gets the information. Does he refuse to give us the information in detail which Mr. Washington has given him ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: If the House desires to have every figure that Mr. Washington has on his sheets, &c., I will bring them down, but I do not think that it is advisable to do so. The report Mr. Washington made is based on a mass of detail which he discovered in his investigations. That report is in the hands of the House. I think it utterly unreasonable to ask for all the figures and all the details which are worked into the report.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The same thing was done by the Minister of Trade and Commerce when the analysis of the census, without request, were laid on the Table. How much was Washington paid ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: He was paid $5 a day all the time he was engaged in the former year. He was also paid $5 a day, and part of the time $3 a day.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: He has been paid a good round sum for his labour and for information that is practically worthless. To enable us to determine whether it is of any value at all, it would be well to furnish the House with all the data.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Reports of commissions may be based on voluminous evidence and the evidence is always reported to the committee. The report is the conclusion drawn from a very large mass of evidence, which the House is no better able to go over than the details referred to here. Not many would want to go over them, but if only one does so wish, there is no reason why they should not be furnished.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: If the originals are to be brought down, that would not cost much, but to make copies would cost considerable.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: There is no reason why the originals should not be brought down and left in charge of the House.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: My hon. friend from Bothwell (Mr. Clancy) can go to the department and consult them there, and I think that would be the simpler way. I would be glad to give the hon. gentleman every facility.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: My hon. friend is entirely too generous. It is his business to give the House the information. No more reasonable request was ever made than I am making now. I presume the hon. gentleman will have no objection to stating to the committee the object of continuing this man in the work of the department.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The object is to find out whether there is any distinct rule of progress, the selling value of the land from one date to another. That has been, to a certain extent, shown by the report of Mr. Washington. But that report is what I might call a specimen to show what has been occurring in parts of the country. As the hon. gentleman knows, the investigation took place only in Prince Edward Island and in the counties of Carleton, Durham and Elgin in Ontario. The facts point to certain conclusions, but if the question is deemed sufficiently important to go on with the investigation, I should be obliged to ask for a vote for the purpose. When that comes up the hon. gentleman will be welcome to discuss the desirability of the investigation. Under this vote it is impossible that that work should be conducted to any sort of conclusion. And so I can say that, so far as this vote is concerned, I am not going to carry it out. But as to what is going to be done in the future I am not prepared to bind myself.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: And yet the hon. minister has not told us the object of this investigation. He said it was to gain information as to the rise and fall of land values. But what is the object of that ? I shall not attribute motives to the hon. gentleman; and he may be able to give reasons. But, I confess that I am so dull that I cannot see it.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I think it is of great importance to the farming community whether lands are rising or falling in value, because it shows, to a great extent whether the agriculture industry is profitable or otherwise. The way to ascertain that would be by a statistical investigation, just as in the case of other economic facts.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Then, I take it that if the hon. gentleman found that land values were falling, he is so confident of the power of his government, that he would take means to prevent that decline.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: If there seemed any way of doing it, we certainly would try. But the lands are rising in value.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Yes, and in spite of the hon. gentleman. It is surprising that the hon. gentleman can have seen so much aud cannot see what a consummate fraud it is. Let the hon. gentleman come to his senses-

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: We will come to the census by and by.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The Minister of Finance is usually a very prudent gentleman. Aud it is a noticeable fact that he has not risked his reputation by saying a word in defence of this scheme. I am sure he does not approve of it-his views are too broad for that. The Minister of Agriculture states that there is nothing in this vote for the purpose of carrying on work of this kiud. If he is prepared to say that he will not ask the House during the present session for anything to continue the work, I am perfectly satisfied that the item should pass-But, if he cannot make that statement 1 think we should insist on our rights to have such information to guide us, for, in the absence of such a declaration we may ail conclude that the hon. gentleman intends later on to ask us for money to continue the work.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I am afraid I cannot pledge myself.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The fact that the item is here is evidence that the hon. minister intends to continue the work for he told us that this was one of the expenses covered by the vote.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: No.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: The hon. gentleman was asked what the money was for, and he stated-

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I gave what was spent on this service last year.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: But what was the use of that -if it does not indicate how this money is to be spent ? Mr. Washington was quoted as one of the gentlemen who were to share this money.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: No.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Or some one else to do this kind of work.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Any work that might turn up.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: But money is not voted for one purpose and used for another.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I meant statistical work.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
Then, in connection with that I was going to say that if the hon. minister thinks to convince the people that by sending a man around to estimate values- Mr. CLANCY.
it is only an estimate, for he gets no reliable information from the registry offices- that he will get facts upon which conclusion can be based, he is very much mistaken. Very few will believe that. As I said before, the only source from which these values can be got even 'approximately is the bureau of industries. I was going to add, when I was interrupted, by the hon. member for North Simcoe (Mr. McCarthy) that, while the information given to the bureau covers estimates that are not exactly correct, the general results are approxi-I mately correct. But it is little less than absurd for the hon. gentleman to pretend that he can get anything of land values by compiling such figures as these in the three counties in Ontario.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: At page D-13 of the Auditor General's Report, there is an item of $2,284.20 for salaries. -Would the hon. minister tell us how many persons were employed and what each received ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: That is under the head of general statistics. If the hon. gentleman will turn back to page D-4, he will find them all recorded- four clerks whose names had been read by the hon. member for East Elgin (Mr. Ingram).

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Cannot the hon. gentleman make up his mind about putting these on the Table ? It cannot be a difficult thing, either to bring down the original or to bring down a copy.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: If the leader of the opposition asks that all this mass of details should be brought down, I will yield to his request; but I think he is asking for something which will be of no earthly use to the House or the country.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I will accept my hon. friend's promise to bring it down if required, and I will consult with my hon. friend from Bothwell, and let the hon. gentleman know if we require it. Of course it is understood we are to discuss that matter on some other item if we desire to do so.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: On concurrence.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: No, I do not mean on concurrence, that is not the arrangement we made.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I cannot allow the hon. gentleman to discuss this item on every other item of my estimates that will come up.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I think when we passed the item of the Statistical Year-book I had a distinct understanding with the hon. gentleman that this matter might be discussed on some subsequent item ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I think that is the case. I think the hon. gentleman could work it in with the other item.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Carried.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: No, let us not have any misunderstanding about our agreement. I distinctly understood from the Minister of Agriculture to-night that anything that might be discussed on the item of the Statistical Year-book, might in the same manner and to the same full extent, be discussed on some subsequent item. Am I wrong about that ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: No, you are not wrong.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Then I say further that if that is to be done, inasmuch as this item is distinctly connected with the previous item, after these documents are brought down, if we require them, I would like to have the same liberty to deal with this particular subject, after making such examination as we might desire of these documents.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: All right.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Are we sure we understand each other ?

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: Yes, I understand the hon. gentleman.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: There is another thing that I would like to mention. I would like the Minister of Agriculture to be prepared with certain information as to what inquiries have been made of census enumerators respecting alleged frauds, before the census item is finally disposed of. I <Io not want to refer to what has taken place in the past. My hon. friend knows he said that he thought he would be able at some future day to furnish me with certain information as to that. I would like to know who the enumerators are who have been communicated with, what the nature of the communication to them was, and what reply was received from them in each instance. I think we should have this information before the census item passes, and that we should have it for a sufficient length of time previously to enable us to examine it in connection with the documents already laid on the Table, for the purpose of discussing the action of the government respecting the investigations made into the census of 1891.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I understand that.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext: I would also like to say to the Minister of Agriculture that, when it will be convenient to him, either on his estimates or at some other time, I shall bring to his attention certain facts in connection with the dismissal of Captain D. C. Stewart, Halifax, who was employed, I think, in connection with the quarantine service. I would like the hon. gentleman to be prepared to discuss that, either on his estimates or at some other time which we can arrange between us.

maintopic: SUPPLY-TELEGRAPHIC COMMUNICA-CATION WITH PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
I will be very glad to. Perhaps it would be convenient for the hon. gentleman to discuss that on the quarantine item.
Some resolutions reported.
